description:
I always think it says "Human!"

Best combination fried rice I could find in this area of Essef!  

Consistently large portions and taste.  It usually has two shrimps on top, a few slices of beef, and a bunch of chopped chicken n pork.  That sesame oil smell...so good!

These guys are bomb!  I'll be back when my grease levels hit dangerously low and needs restoring.

Thanks, Henry!
author: John M.

description:
Don't get these:
Scallion pancake
Dumplings
Beef with scallions 

Warning!  
Not authentic at all.
How could you screw up on scallion pancakes?
Secondly, we were the only Chinese people in the restaurant. Sign number two. Even the hot & sour soup was diluted. 

If this isn't convincing, just check the pictures of my scallion pancake. 

It has a high rating but probably because of the lack of alternatives.
My friend kept saying the best item was the water not even to be funny. But I agree because it drained the poor taste away. The servers were nice though, can't complain much about that.
author: Linda L.

description:
Have been here many times, and today I decided to go for the Kung Pao Chicken. The next table over had ordered it, and it seemed like a large plate of diced, sauteed chicken with soy sauce, bamboo shoots, ginger, nuts, etc., and it looked really good. So I got it with steamed rice. I also asked for it to be made spicy.

And let me tell you this: it was the best kung pao chicken I have ever had, period! The portion and the flavor were absolutely fantastic. Priced at $12, I thought it was a good deal. If anything, I would say that they should not be charging extra for the steamed rice, which they did, which is why I am giving them 4 stars. But definitely worth trying. I also noticed that they serve individual dishes, and not have everything bunched together under a 'lunch special' menu, as most Chinese restaurants do. I thought this was a very good value!
author: Raj D.

description:
Not bad Chinese place tucked away in a side street. Looks Tony from the outside but the place is huge so getting a table is no problem!

Service is ok, they aren't super attentive so you really need to flag them down when your easy to order/pay or have any sort of question. While there were only a few tables seated while we were there, this made service rather slow.

Food was overall pretty good! If you have any hesitation towards spice let them know. They do have a disclaimer that the dishes are spicy as this style of cuisine is, so be aware of that when ordering and make sure to notify them if you want mild. I love spice do for me all the dishes were great and very flavorful. The 5 spice tofu was really good and they have many tofu dishes for vegetarians. 

Overall food was quite good and portions were size able as they are family style, but would probably do takeout from here on out!
author: Rachel K.

description:
This place is good ask for the fresh red chili with scallions its addictive!!!
Good place for a work lunch not too pricey big portions but amazing flavour....its a must
author: Anjana P.

description: New seasonal special,love that Chinese tea with chia seeds:) The taste is as good as the appearance! Hunan beef also reminded me of my hometown food!!!
author: Fiona F.

description:
One of the things I miss about not working in the city is not being able to go to Henry's Hunan. Their chilli sauce is like crack!! I want it!!!! And I don't even like spicy food.

Everything here is good. My faves are the onion cakes and the kung pao chicken. The place is not much to look at it but serves up tasty food!
author: Sunil R.

description: Can't complain - got the Mongolian beef, spicy, which was delicious and I couldn't really ask for more. It was delicious and filling at the same time. Great food.
author: Neechi M.

description:
Today I went here for lunch and left extremely disappointed. I arrived with ample time to be able to dine in. After ordering my food I noticed that several people that came in after me where getting their plates. When asking for an update the waitress she either didn't make eye contact and by passed me then said it was coming. 30+ minutes later it arrived for just enough time for me to box it up and walk back to work. She even had the nerve to gesture about a tip! I have a tip, first in first out. It's a general food policy that works well.

Food: didn't like what I ordered but maybe would of been ok if I order something else but service is why you recieved 1 star.
author: Jade S.

description: Love this place! Always get the "steamed noodles with ground pork" and the dumplings. Bomb!
author: Nicole M.

description: Over the years, I've grown a fondness for the food at Henry's Hunan. The food between the different locations is consistent and the dishes are tasty. It's a certain kind of spicy, not daly hot but quite flavorful. On a recent visit to this location, we got there at 5pm, when they opened for dinner and there were about two other tables there. The servers were still vacuuming and setting up for the evening so that was a tad annoying. It was a Monday night and when I called on Wednesday, they assured me that it would be a slow night and I wouldn't need reservations for a party of 7. It also meant I could have any pick of a round table and it would be quiet enough for the meeting I had planned except for the loud vacuuming. For dinner, we started off with the Mu Shu Soup for the table and it was filled with chunks of tofu and veggies such as spinach. The broth was very flavorful. Then we shared a family style meal of Green Beans with Shrimp, Stir Fried Broccoli, Chicken Chow Mein,  Shredded Pork, Mongolian Beef, and steamed rice. All the dishes were tasty and the portions were just right. Each dish had its own unique flavor and variety of fresh ingredients. For seven of us, we each spent only $16 and that includes tip! It seems a little crazy we got away with full bellies for so cheap in the FiDi/SOMA. All the dishes were tasty and the portions were just right.
author: Jen L.

description:
My girlfriend and I were looking for some local San Francisco flavor in terms of Chinese food, that offered takeout options. After searching some places, only to find that their health ratings were below average, we finally found a place with a good rating and a long string of happy customers. 

We got two entree dishes, one order of fried rice with shrimp and one order of Henry's velvet chicken. We also got an order of dumplings and a an order of the onion cakes because of a review we read. However we had to drive a bit to get to our hotel, so they were kinda cold, flat and tasteless when we tried them. So maybe they would've been better hot and fresh. 
On the other hand, all of the food was delicious, I especially liked the dumplings. And we didn't have any leftovers!

Nice staff, cool location, and reasonable prices considering its location within the city, we would definitely go back again!!
author: Brock M.

description:
Good ol' Henry's Hunan Restaurant. They've been around for years at this location and can you believe it's been over 10 years since I last ate here? I do remember the place and was excited to see if anything changed since my last visit. 

I ordered the kung pao chicken for pickup at 11:45am. The restaurant was slowly getting busy and my goal was to beat the lunch hour rush. I was instructed to pick up my order at the counter. They do appear to be new in the business because they were discussing putting up signage for Mealpal. I went up to the counter, gave them my name and I was off. 

The portion was very generous and the chicken had plenty of spice. The red hot chilies were blackened so I plucked them out. The reviews complained of too many onions but I thought it was just fine. The upside is they had everything ready to go and the food was still hot by the time I brought it back to the office. Definitely bonus points on them for being so well organized. 

I remember what I ordered way back when. It was smoked ham with string beans. Ah the memories...
author: Tim G.

description:
Only negative i really have is getting there on a Wednesday at 6 pm.  It had been a long tine since I've been there last, like 15 years.  Shrimp and tofu = very good.
Mongolian beef = pretty good
Smoked ham = overrated
Hot chili oil = purchased (noy made onsite)
Price = not cheap Chinese
Service = good when slow

3.5 stars
author: Dan S.

description: Pretty authentic Chinese restaurant, unlike others that put way too much oil or way too heavy seasoning. This one continues to be my favorite food-made-by-mommy :-)
author: Isabelle L.

description: Met an old friend for lunch here and wasn't blown away by the food. I ordered Mongolian beef & he got the garlic chicken with a side of white rice. The beef was very tender but the flavor could have been much stronger in comparison to versions I've had from other places. The garlic chicken was real bland & disappointing to the point my friend didn't even care to finish & after tasting it myself I didn't care to either. Service was very friendly and it has a nice size dining space although it does get crowded during lunch hour.
author: LeVar H.

description:
Large place and good place to get food with large group. There are many kind of menu and good to share with many people.

I think A taste of food is great. But some foods have strong taste. Check before order.

Service is not so good not too bad. But If you seat side of the reataurant, server may not see you often. 

Resonable price, and amout of food is pretty lot. For two people, one plate and fried rice or noddle is enough.
author: Da Won L.

description: I've been here a few times for dinner. The first time was really early and the food tasted great. The second and third times were at later times and I've noticed that the later we came, the saltier the food tasted until the most recent time when I wasn't able to enjoy it at all. My guess is that the salt is accumulating in the cooking area throughout the evening.
author: Lucy T.

description:
The food is okay, nothing special. But they have the worst service. The waitress brought one dish and then the next 20 minutes later when I asked her politely where the other dish was and she acted as if I was unconvincing
her. Also, I asked if they could put the broccoli on the side in the chow mein and the waitress said that she can either put it in the dish or not nothing on the side? How is that possible? You just put it on a plate? And worst of all they never gave us water. I had to signal for her and she didn't even come over she expected me to shout across the room I need water like I'm a child. This place is not worth their crappy customer service!
author: Mehnoosh A.

description: Kung Pao Tofu is easily the best I have had in the bay area (and it is one of my go-to dishes in Chinese places, so I've tried lots of variants of it). This one is spicy (you can request milder) and flavorful.  Dine in can be a little slow at lunch time - the place gets busy! To go has always been fast for me. They have free Wi-Fi if you do end up waiting.
author: John G.

description: Like traditional Chinese food.i felt it really good place and position for someone who live in San Francisco
author: Meng Z.

description: I came here with my girlfriend last week. We were really hungry. Ordered a lot of food. I liked the velvet chicken, and shrimp and tofu. Fried rice was good too. My girlfriend was not too thrilled about her food, but liked mine. Service was mediocre, waiter was rushing but did perform her basic duties. Will we be back or recommend this place? May be.
author: Dennis L.

description:
A solid 2.5 star restaurant for the low price. Just be careful what you order, as the quality and taste of the food ranges from unbearable to decent...

I wouldn't recommend it for a nice dinner, but won't stop you for a quick lunch.
author: Straight N.

description: Wow, what an outstanding family style experience, especially with a large group!!  Everyone I have brought here to eat has enjoyed it and left in a great mood.  This has been my "go to" spot the last 5 years when I'm in the bay area and is a must try in my book.  It is kinda an off the beaten path hole in the wall, the food might take a while and their communication skills might not be the best, but man, their food is soooooooo worth it IMO.
author: Tommy D.

description: Some of the best food I've ever had!! I tell everyone, if you want good Chinese food go to any of the Hunan spots. Thanks guys!
author: Mira M.

description:
This place has gone downhill since the last time I was there about 7 years ago.

That meat pie is still great, but the service and the room and the entrees are poor (and that is generous)

The do not have hot mustard or brown rice (2 standard Asian food items)

The Thursday special is still black bean chicken - which I used to love, but this was all full of too many onions and the chicken was full of unchewable bits.  

Food has to be pretty bad for me to not take home the leftovers and I left them.
author: Amy W.

description:
This is our go-to place for farewell luncheons. 

This is like an Asian mom-n-pop kinda establishment where its all about the food. Get in early coz people start lining up around 11 am for lunch.

Do not skip their onion pancake. Its just out of the world. We order one pancake for 4 of us. Perfect for sharing. All of their items are huge portions, so we usually order the following and its plenty for all of us:
- 1 onion pancake (dip it in the spicy sauce on the table)
- 2 egg fried rice
- Mongolian beef (my favorite) OR velvet chicken 
- Kung Pao shrimp

Once we were there at closing time and were seated next to these women who were folding potstickers. What a treat to watch. Everything was neat and clean and they put a lot of care into making them potstickers. That itself is telling of why the food here is so good.
author: Sujeesha V.

description:
I love their tomato egg soup.  It is slightly more expensive than the soups on the menu, but I like it much better than all the other soups. 
Because it is not on the menu and when they are busy they can't make it. 
I also like their spicy sour beef, and gizzard.  

Their services are very good too. Very friendly.
author: Yumi K.

description: First time trying it out today very good got the kung pao chicken a la carte with rice ,Definitely coming back soon .
author: Ratani S.

description: Ate here tonight and it was wonderful! Clean space, friendly service, GREAT food!!! Very impressed and would definitely return!!
author: Brittney W.

description: Few of our friends recommended this place and it was a total hit with my husband and I. We ordered Diana's special meat pie (AMAZING), Kung pao chicken and fried rice. They even make an"Indian chili" which is a spicer hot chili oil for those to are like it kicked up a notch. We are from Houston, and this has got to be one of the best Chinese restaurants we have visited or eaten at in a very long time. Kudos to the owners
author: Hena P.

description:
One of my reliable favorite Chinese spots in the city, so much so I'm here with my sister at least once every few weeks. We used to frequent Hunan on Sansome Street for the last 20 or so years, but Natoma is our new favorite. It's a place we go when we want a super filling yummy meal in a casual setting, not a place we'd necessarily take friends staying the weekend for a particularly memorable or special meal.

A couple of our staple order items include Diana's meat pie, dumplings, chicken salad, and curry chicken. They are happy to kick up the spicy factor on any dish, but I find the dishes tend to be pretty spicy on their own, like the dumplings which are served in a hot chili oil sauce. I also realize a lot of the reviews complain about grease and oil, and the meat pie and dumplings certainly have a decent amount of oil in them and I can see how that'd be a turn off. They're still my two favorite starters to get...

The food is always served fast and piping hot. Eternally craving my next meal here. Greasy or not, I still love Henry's Hunan!
author: Chelsea P.

description: Not very tasty, portions have almost no beef (they brought plates of onions). On the up side, its quite cheap.
author: Luis C.

description: You will not be disappointed! Food is very tasty and you'll be hooked! Not too many Chinese restaurants around SOMA District that can compare!
author: E C.

description:
A server checks more than we ordered.
I think he makes that 'mistake' intentionally because it was 3rd time just for me.
 Be careful but food tastes good.
author: Changmin L.

description: I wanted something comfort food simple and the orange chicken and fried rice more than satisfied.  Well done HH.
author: Sergio H.

description:
Got introduced to this place by a colleague and really didn't know what to expect.  They pretty much dish things out like a factory with the waitstaff just checking boxes on their little sheet which was just a mini version of the menu.  We got the ham and green beans and the fish and a small bowl of sweet and sour soup to share.  Food is pretty standard and really nothing great.  Good for a quick bite to eat for lunch.

The place was heaving at lunch because it's very fast service and you pay for your lunch at the counter.

Over all just so/so.
author: Nyla K.

description: Their food is great.  I was intrigued by their meat pie so I thought I'd give it a try and it was awesome!  I've now gone back for it twice, it's like a Chinese taco.  And the owner Frank is a super nice guy.
author: Eugene T.

description:
Came for dinner with a a coworker after hearing great things from a friend. The server staff was friendly and we got seated right away at a roomie table. Tea was perfect and our appetizers came quickly. We got a meat pie and it was probably the most nice give dish I've ever tried at a Chinese restaurant...put some chilli paste in there and it's off the charts.

Pro tip- They even have a loyalty rewards program so you can get free dumplings next visit!! will be going back soon for those free dumplings
author: Justin H.

description: I've been coming here for a number of years whenever I have projects in the area; to be clear, the only thing I order here, are potstickers, to go, I admittedly am a potsticker fanatic. Tried them today and they taste just as great as they have in years past; 6 for $6.80. Definitely give them an "A" rating. One of these days, will get 3 orders to go! Highly recommend that you call ahead on orders to go, especially around lunch time, as it gets very busy there.  I would have posted a pik, but I ate them too quick :)
author: Steve M.

description:
Felt like having some Chinese food and decided to try Hunans' for lunch.

Paid $15+ for a piece of crap sweet and sour chicken dish. It tastes super horrible and not fresh. Meat was soggy fried, old, and tough. Considering how bad it was the small portion was a plus. Please remove this disaster off your menu... forever. Panda Express is way cheaper but is five stars compared to this.

Banned!
author: Han T.

description: The very best.  Whenever I am in San Francisco, I visit Henry's Hunan and make sure I take back four entrees to Los Angeles with bottles of pepper sauce.  The hot and sour chicken and kung pao chicken very, very, very spicy with all the wonderful flavors is awesome.  Very delicious and spicy.  They have many wonderful dishes.  This location is special because Henry's grandson is manager and maintains the highest quality with the right amounts of ingredients.  I always order very, very spicy.
author: James B.

description:
I used to frequent this place when Ed was around running this place.  The veggies are quite meager in the veggie chow mien, you might as well call it "chinese spaghetti with scant veggies".  The veggies in the fried rice are 100% frozen peas and carrots based on their uniformity. The fried rice was bland.  The chicken was chewy indicating less white meat and more of the fat laden dark meat which is not only cheaper but ubiquitous in chinese restaurants at the food court.    

The taste and the quality hasn't evolved over the years, so maybe it's my taste buds craving fresher options.
author: Vindaloo M.

description: Definitely my favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. Great service, AMAZING food. Food comes out almost instantly after ordering (sometimes almost seems like fast food!). Quality is great-- very traditional, huge selection. Highly recommend! Be sure to order the Diana's Meat Pie!
author: Clara C.

description:
I have driven from Las Vegas - 530 miles each way - just to go to this restaurant.  Without question, Henry's Hunan has the best authentic Hunan style cuisine anywhere in the United States.  I strongly recommend Marty's Special. 

Make sure to pick up the cookbook before leaving. 

The best restaurant in the San Francisco Bay Area.
author: Will M.

description: The BEST! Marty's Special, Diana's Meatpie....country vegetables.  To die for!  The nicest employees!
author: Mary F.

description: Delicious. Really authentic Chinese food at a fair price!
author: Florian K.

description: I come here almost every week. It is usually very busy during lunch time, especially on Friday. To save waiting time, it is recommended to come here before 11:50AM. Typical Hunan spicy foods. And most of their waiters and waitresses are from Hunan, China. You can ask for very/middle/little spicy when ordering you food.
author: TM P.

description:
Back at a Henry's after ages. Ate at the original on Kearny Street when some magazine ( New Yorker? ) said that this was the best Chinese restaurant in the U.S., and an anonymous local Chinese reporter said it wasn't even the best on its block, prompting Henry to make it the only restaurant on the block ( I think ).

Well, the onion cakes are less greasy than before and the Mongolian Beef and the Kung Pao dishes are fantastic. I wish that they still had the "bacon".

I do not know if the Chung family is still in charge, but this place is pretty darn good!
author: George T.

description:
Worst place ever

We order a dish, it doesn't turn out to be the dish we wanted. I spoke to the manager and asked to replace the dish. She was being very stingy and refused to replace the dish. We had no choice but force to eat the disgusting dishes that they gave us.  The meat was really burn and two dishes actually share the same kind of disgusting vegetables. I am not sure if they are lazy, or they just don't care. How can you share vegetables for two different dishes and it tastes the same level of disgustingness. Honestly, I am not sure how this place still exist.  

The meat taste so bad. We requested to switch the dish and have them make it over again. The manager refused...So they said no!. Their manager yelled at me and said this is what you order. Yes, it is fine, but does your menu mention this dish is not supposed to be DISGUSTING ? NO! You should label it on the menu and say this dish is very disgusting so I won't order it. I got tricked by the picture. I don't think it is the communication issues , because ALL the dishes taste burnt and DISGUSTING. The only way I can order the RIGHT food is to go to another restaurant. I won't order any piece of their food ever again.

 My friend told them to add some chicken piece to the other plate and the waiter said sure. ( 
 The waiter didn't mentioned it costs 5 bucks !! ). Everything is a scram there, I am not recommending anyone going there. And please, their yelp reviewed probably is fake. They probably give money to some people to help them take out the negative review and make the review better.
author: Kevin Z.

description:
When people tell me that they know a good Chinese place, I am usually the last one to believe them.

I grew up with Chinese food, so I am super picky when people say its good.

Henry's Hunan falls under the "ehhhh, I am not a person that will come back". I got Kung Pao Beef and it was disappointing.

First off it was too saucy and oily. I love sauce, but the saucy seem watery and lacked flavor. Granted it was spicy, but that was it. It seemed one-note and had no real flavor expect bamboo shoots.

Another issue that bugged me was that it used so much canned items: bamboo shoot and mushrooms, with the real veggies, super overcooked. 

The egg rolls (which i tried for the hell of it) seemed like they were just kept warm and had no seasoning at all. I have bought ones at Ranch 99 that had more flavor.

If you want a hole in the wall Chinese, Tai San in Berkeley is better.
For upscale, China Village in Albany.

After rating the lack of flavor and the price, I will not be coming back. I could have gotten a foot-long at Subway for less money and would have tasted better.
author: Mei L.

description:
My friends insisted that we visit Henry's Hunan for lunch and not knowing much about the food scene in this area, I obliged and joined them. We headed to lunch at 11:30 which is a little on the early side for lunch but they wanted to avoid the crowds. 

They started out with Diane's pie which looked beautiful but I opted out because I don't always love pork.  We shared a small hot and sour soup which was filled with lots of yummy goodness. It was big enough to share with at least 5 people and only $4.50. 
We moved on to the green beans with chicken which was my favorite, I pretty much cleaned that plate. It was packed with so much flavor and spice.  I like spicy foods so I asked for it to be extra spicy.  They gave generous portions of rice so keep that in mind when ordering. We rounded out our lunch with Henry's Special which had a little bit of everything - scallops, chicken, shrimp and sautéed veggies.

Nice spot.
author: Dorothy H.

description:
Came to Henry's Hunan for lunch today and was less than unimpressed, yes you read that correctly. We got a sampling of many dishes - kung pao chicken, mushupork, a vegetable dish, dumplings, and marinated squid. Tell me why, out of all of those dishes everything tasted the exact same? The best thing we got was the white rice - it had more flavor than any of the dishes! No joke, they used the same four ingredients in every single dish. Green bell pepper, onion, bamboo shoots, and flavorless generic sauce. While this kitchen prides themselves on spicy, what spice? They even had, what I would call, a white people menu that said "for those that don't like red hot chili flakes." Why was their "spicy" a white people spicy? I'm terrified for what the white people menu tasted like. This is a Hunan kitchen, are you kidding? I said spicy, not white people spicy - get outta here! They got me fucked up that the kung pao beef tasted exactly like the marinated vegetables.

Their menu had a big "no MSG" symbol on it, but really what it should have said was "no spice or flavor." I would consider this place a misdemeanor crime but after they don't even give you fortune cookies - heinous felonious criminals!! Lol

I will not be back, ever.

In a nut shell: No spice. No flavor. No fortune cookies. No good. No returning.
author: Gina G.

description:
Through the alley ways of downtown San Francisco you're likely to walk past and/or not even see the entrance door to Henry's Hunan restaurant, but I tell you it's well worth the hunt.  This unassuming location offers a large dining area outfitted in the customary Chinese decor with space enough for several simultaneous large parties. I understand that it get's very crowded during the lunch-rush and after this experience I can see why.

You're Welcomed: Friendly staff greet and seat you based on availability.  Since this was a late lunch we were the only persons in the entire restaurant dining and therefore we had our pick of the room.

Simple enough, Good food:  The food was really very good.  We decided to order our favorites (why mess with a good thing?): Kung Pao Beef and Sweet and Sour Chicken.  Though spicy the beef had just the right amount of heat to it.  The chicken was sweetened just enough for you to enjoy the tender meat without being overwhelmed by a thick, syrup that I've become used to at other establishments that I've been to.

Bang-for-the-Buck:  Very reasonable prices for the amount and taste of the food.  You will definitely appreciate the quality, quantity and the price your pay for your meal.  Best to bring a large group so you can also sample everyone's order.

The Long-and-the-Short:  If you're ever in the downtown area, craving some good Chinese food, and don't have time to make it over to China town, come here for lunch or dinner.  You may have to do a little hunting and pecking to find the door, but it will be well worth the effort.  

You MUST eat here!
author: Philip T.

description: Onion pancakes are great, add the hot sauce on the table and you'd be glad you ordered it. Monogolian bbq, king pao shrink, and shrimp fried rice are all tasty. The quality is amazing and I'd definitely be back here! Portion sizes are good for sharing so order one dish if eating for two. My 2 cents.
author: Dennis S.

description: Best food!! Favorites for everyone! Very good prices! I have celiac and they make all my food gluten free. I've never had a reaction. My fiance has a list of allergies and they are always flexible. All of our friends without allergies love it too. Can't go wrong.
author: Marissa D.

description:
Love the heat, love the spice combinations of Hunan-style food, and love the jumbled-up atmosphere.

Packed shoulder-to-shoulder sometimes, which is a drag. Service is wildly erratic in quality, which is also a drag.

I keep going, so something must be right about the place...
author: Doc M.

description: This is our go to place for hunan food and definitely the one of the best in the SF area. Good for large groups and plenty of options to chose from. Service has been a little varying standards off late and some times had to wait too for food.
author: Bhushan A.

description: Very oily food. 3 of us ordered food and the first dish arrived in 15 and the last dish arrive in 45 min. Service is not good and prices are not even less expensive that other places. So I do not get the false popularity. Will not go there again.
author: Nariman R.

description:
Food here is so cheap - especially in the Financial District area!

3 girls who ordered up 6 dishes.  With the huge, saucy portions, the total came out to be about $50 - not including tip.  Plus, we had leftovers.

Most of their stir-fried dishes were drenched in sauce and oil.  I usually like sauce, but theirs were not commendable and simply average.  The Veggie Chow Mein helped with the absorbing of the sauce.

Their meat pie stood out the most to me because it was not only different, it reminded me of a quesadilla without the cheese and beans!  

Service was alright and decor of the place had a bit of a Chinese theme to it.  It's an affordable, good place to eat at with groups.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Order was ready fast. I order spring roll the had no flavor. I also ordered a chicken chow mein big portion and had a lot of flavor. Worth the $10.
author: Sila C.

description:
The bell weather of Chinese Food in San Francisco.

Consistency, High Quality, Authentic and the staff are great. 

Hunan at its finest and the heat/spice factor is off the charts good. Hot with flavor. 

Yes, you can get it mild, but don't wuss out!! :))
author: James G.

description:
Fairly generic Americanized Chinese food place in the Soma area. The place seemed to have been around for a long time, with the stereotypical "Introduction to the Chinese Zodiac" posters on the tables and wall etc.

I ordered the Beef noodles which had great noodles, but the beef wasn't that great (a little chewy).  The broth was pretty good--pretty much within expectations.

Overall I would say this is an average chinese food place. If you like Americanized Chinese food, or if you are just looking for Chinese food in the Financial district area, this is a good place to stop by.
author: Henry L.

description:
Worst ever restaurant in my entire US stay (16 years)..
1. Waiter does not even turn up for taking order for full 30-min, after serving water
2. After taking the order again full 30-min for serving it. Not in full - first to my friend and after a 15-min wait mine. My friend could not start due to being sensitive. In between, when we asked for status of my order, another person says -rudely says..wait..it will take time..No courtesy what so ever
3. I ordered for Veg fried rice. And what I get is a rice with mix of frozen carrot and peas, cooked in oil. This is not a Veg. fried rice by any means/standards. 
4. After giving the bill promptly, no one comes to collect it after putting the credit card.
5. Finally, when we went to pay, the sign-board says..no more than 2-credit cards per bill. And after paying without a tip (tip for what???), the lady asks why no tip. (N)Ever seen anyone asking for tip?

Please do not show up - if you are vegetarian and expecting good service..

Surprised these guys are in the business.
author: Suresh M.

description:
I've had lunch here so often, I cannot believe I haven't left a review. I l o v e this place. Amazing food, wonderful staff, quick (though there's a line to get in 12-1:00). 

Hunan Smoked Ham: Amazing
Beef Stock With veggies and potstickers: as satisfying as pho on a rainy day.
Curt Chicken n veg on Wednesday: yes, please.

Do your tummy a favor and get your seat now. 
YUMM!
author: David S.

description: This was my first time to eat my hometown food in America. I cried when I ate those such delicious food. And they talked to me in dialect after they knew we are from the same place. In a word, nice service, delicious food, everything is perfect in there!
author: Qiyixin Z.

description: Waited over 40 minutes for my food during a lunch break after being told it would take 20. Party that got seated after me got their food before me and I only ordered sweet and sour pork and rice. So I left hungry with no food and no explanation as to what took so long. Probably won't be coming back here.
author: Donna R.

description:
Convenient location in SoMa, but the food was just a little too greasy for me.  WE had a party of nine hungry people and ordered all over the menu family style.

Dumplings, Meat Pie, Vegetarian egg rolls, Hunan String Beans, Smoked Ham and Green Beans, Deep Fried Tofu, Brown Rice, Mongolian Beef, Spareribs, several rounds of beer, and few items I don't seem to remember.  The bill came up to 150 bucks plus tip.

All the food started to have the same oily background taste.  I am not saying the food was bad, just a little greasy for me.  Some of the food had an old taste if that makes sense.

The Smoked Ham was a little salty, the egg rolls were bland, pot stickers were okay but the skins were thick, Mongolian Beef was very flavorful, Tofu was good, Spareribs were okay - black bean style, Meat pie was not what I was expecting - two flour tortilla sandwiching some lettuce and ground meat. Green beans were cooked just right - just a little greasy.  Service was good but not enough to make a difference...

Considering all the great Chinese restaurant in this city, this is not on my best in the city list.
author: Mike R.

description:
This is one of the many locations of Henry's Hunan and the second location I've tried. The food is consistent but how badly can you misstep on these dishes? 

I ordered for pick up and of course, it was not ready by the time I came in. The cashier is short, unmemorable, and just trying to get through the long lines of people wanting to pay. 

They don't have the daily specials like the Sacramento location, or at least I didn't see any indication of such. 

Totally higher priced Chinese food but it is the Financial District so you can't be surprised. I actually entered from the back entrance on Minna and I didn't realize it was the back entrance until I walked it. Convenient that they keep it open for easy access from Mission Street. 

The food is the same. Greasy, good chinese food, but nothing incredibly special. $2 for rice -- excessive, but I'm sure this was intentional as they have a limited "lunch rice plate" specials list. You have to order an entree of what you want, plus the rice... Smart.
author: Jeannie L.

description: Decent Hunan cuisine with some unique dishes in the mix. Try Diana's meat pie, I can only compare it to a Taco Bell Mexican pizza but much better of course - though on the greasy side so you've been warned. Although it's Hunan, not a ton of spice unless we got all the wrong dishes. Overall, plates are flavorful and great for groups.
author: Gonzalo S.

description: Been here a few times, and it's incredibly good, spicy, full of flavor, solid Chinese. The potstickers and hot and sour soup can't be beat--I know it's the cliched white guy order, but it's what I always get there, and they do a good job. I'm giving it 3 stars because the service is abrupt, and sometimes downright rude. Last time they actually spilled the soup on the table and didn't bother to wipe it, not even after I asked. I got water only after I asked three times, and they kept bringing it with ice, even though I kept asking for it without. It mars the whole experience, but if I go with a large group late at night, and keep my expectations low for service, this place hits the spot for my late night Hunan cravings .
author: Art I.

description:
Came with low expectations and still left disappointed. Other yelpers recommended these dishes so we got them:
- Diana's beef pie - 1 star. Do not bother. It's just ground beef and Parmesan cheese with subway lettuce. 
- Beef noodle soup - 2 stars. Noodles are good, broth is bland, meat is ok. 
- String beans with smoked ham - 3 stars. The only semi-redeeming dish of this place, the meat was flavorful but overall too salty. 

The service was good, but that doesn't help when the food isn't great.
author: Inga C.

description:
We've had Henry's Hunan catered for a bunch of lunch meetings, because their catering and delivery is excellent.  You can order an hour before you need it, and they deliver hot and fresh food on time and in abundance.

The order usually varies, but it's generally some subset of the Mongolian beef, the Kung pao chicken, the string beans, the curry chicken, the mixed veggies, and the kung pao tofu.

Personally, my favorites are the Mongolian beef, the Kung pao chicken, and the string beans.  The food is spicy and full of flavor, and it's easy to overindulge. A few downsides are the food is sometimes oily and salty, and the kung pao chicken always has too many peanuts and onions.

I'm sure we'll keep ordering at work until we get sick of it, and then we'll find something else to order and get sick of! :)
author: Nadeem A.

description: It is a very traditional Chinese restaurant. It is very popular. A lot of people are waiting there. The environment is nice and the waiters are so nice. I ordered noodles with stewed beef and rice plates with beef&vegetables. They taste good.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Do yourself a favor and don't eat here.  This is a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant (which I am not opposed to), but the food here is just really awful.  I don't have high expectations but even my other co-workers I went with during lunch, agreed that the food is just extremely unflavorful, bland, and just awful tasting.  

So in the event that you're forced to eat here against your will, do yourself a favor and prepare to spend money on a 2nd lunch at another place.  It was so bad, I ended up walking a few blocks up and grabbing a subway sandwich to wash down the horrible hunanny from Henry.  

On a side note, the place is dirty (I can live with) and the waiter won't care about refilling your water, but will ask you every minute if you're done with your plate so that he can clear your dishes.  It's not about the quality of the food, cleanliness, or courteous service....the only thing that matters is whether or not they can clear the dishes off your table so that the next victim can come sit down and waste their money.
author: Louis V.

description: I was the first person to get in for lunch... 30 minutes has passed, then the restaurant is full and everyone is eating except me... I asked about my food and it's another 10 minutes before I finally get my food... and the waitress did apologize, but her excuse was lame. She said, they had to put in group orders 1st before mine... I guess it's not, 1st come 1st served here. Lam, lame, lame!!!
author: CB C.

description: Smells terrible and food is the same.  We came in and no one attempted to come seat us.  We should have left then.  Then you get hit with the smell of scaled cooking oil.  I wanted to leave but person with me said no let's order.  We ordered and I was too afraid to eat the meal as the smell of burnt oil was so bad.
author: Kris G.

description: This place is good for an okay, quick, sit down lunch.  Lots of seating.  Big menu, but all looked the same.  I ordered mongolian beef with a side of rice (was not one of the over rice specials so cost more).  Got it mild, but didn't realize that mild meant no spice at all.  It was bland, nothing special, but good enough to eat when hungry.  I'll give it another try and have it spicy next time.
author: Joanne T.

description:
More like 3.5 stars, but I gave it the extra .5 star because of service.

A good friend (which I like to call her one of my sisters from another mister) drove up from San Jose and wanted to try out a place. First off, we wanted to go somewhere cheap but not quality wise. Second, we didn't want to venture off TOO far from Downtown San Francisco. Also, we both didn't have a chance to check Yelp for any good places around, so we did something DARING, we just wandered around until we found something good.

We first went to Kyo-Ya, because her GPS system recommended it, but saw it was a bit out of price range. As we were ABOUT to head to Tempura House, we found this hole-in-the-wall and debated about it for a while. She did ask me if Chinese food was okay, and I flat out said, "I'll eat anything, just to get Yelp review."  And so we took our chances.

At first glance, we thought it was PRETTY dead, until we got seated in the back, which had a decent amount of people at tables. Taking our chances again, we ordered the Hunan Velvet Chicken (I decided on this dish because of the vegetables and "velvet" drew me towards this) and the Hot and Sour Pork (my friend is always in the mood for hot and sour entrees). Also, we ordered the onion cakes, because my friend wanted one.

My friend did ask me how the decor was. I said that it has a cozy atmosphere, a bit grungy, but cozy, even with the steel pillars running perpendicular to the floor made it cozy. Also, she did point out the fact that the kitchen was in plain view, with nothing blocking the way of how the chefs made our dishes.

- The onion cake (yes, CAKE, not cakes) was different from what I'm used to, a more brown deep-fried style pancake, with very little spring onion popping out from the skin, but more buried within the layers. Tasty, but kind of wished it came with a dipping sauce. (It might be a Hunan region thing, but I'm not 100% sure).

- The velvet chicken had an interesting taste. The veggies that came with it was delicious, but the chicken itself was kind of bland. Kind of wished that the chicken was marinated beforehand with the sauce that the dish came with; would have made the dish better.

- The hot and sour pork was mixed. My friend said that she didn't like it so much, because it was deep fried a bit TOO long. At first, I didn't noticed it, since I'm LOVE fried things (like tempura, donuts, french fries, etc.) but I did see where she was coming from. The pork was left in the fryer a bit TOO long, because I did taste some burnt pieces here and there. Sauce was good, and plenty of veggies.

I do like the fact the waiters were attentive, asking how our meal was and offered to refill our rice bowl when it gone empty.

Prices were a little bit on the higher scaled, in comparison to what I'm used to in Los Angeles, but I do understand that San Francisco tends to be a bit more expensive.

Something that I don't see everyday, the fortune cookie is in a jar, and you have to use tongs to fish one out. My friend and I got one, and was surprised that it wasn't under or over baked. However, it could from the place they get their shipment from, not because they make the cookies themselves.
author: Tom T.

description: This place is top notch. It's in a random alley but check it out. Get the Ham and peas that's one of the best dishes. Good prices with $4 beers.
author: Shawn T.

description: Food quality is good, if you're willing to wait 45 minutes for your food. This place is so understaffed you could probably buy the ingredients from a grocery store, cook it yourself and be faster than them serving you. So go at your own discretion.
author: Davis W.

description:
Since our last visit we have stopped at Henry's twice.  One time it was late/mid day -- the restaurant doors were open, workers were sitting around, and a few tables looked like people had just left.  The guy behind the counter told us they were closed, closed, closed.  O.K. so we left.
Today we tried them again, yes they were open.  They were out of spring rolls and dumplings -- it was noon on a Friday so this isn't an odd hour, we were kind of disappointed, so we settled for the crispy pancake appetizer which is always tasty.  We asked for spicy oil and were told no, they only have the Vietnamese Sriracha -- o.k., but isn't this a Chinese restaurant?  Whatever.
My partner ordered his usual dish of spicy tofu with meat sauce which he says is always good.
I was going to order the veggie chow mein but asked the server if I could have veggie chow fun instead which she said was fine.  She brought me fried rice.  When I told her I asked for chow fun (which are wide flat noodles) she argued with me and told me that fried rice WAS chow fun.  Really?  I told her to just bring me the veggie chow mein.
I may look like a stupid white woman but I've lived with a Chinese family long enough to know that chow fun IS NOT fried rice!  And your server should not argue with customers.
My partner might come back when he is in the city because he likes your spicy tofu, but I've run out of options with your place.
author: Victoria S.

description:
We were looking for a good Chinese restaurant near our hotel and found it in Henry's.  It looks a little sketchy from the outside, but it's been around for nearly 40 years. It's not going anywhere.

And that's a good thing because while the menu looks dated and the decor is nothing to speak of, the food is quite good. We started with a small hot & sour soup which might as well feed 4.  Nice and spicy without being too peppery. A good sign. (Still not my all time favorite, but pretty good nonetheless).

We also had the spring rolls (tasty).   The dumplings too were good. The hit of the meal with actually the one I least expected -- the glass noodles with pork. It was surprisingly full of flavor and with lots of texture.  Good stuff.

we also enjoyed Henry's shredded pork; the bok choy/spinach was very tasty without being bitter. A very tough act to achieve.

Less of a hit was the fish which had too much tofu masquerading as fish. Nevertheless, even our young dining companions enjoyed it too.  

The food can be spicy so if you don't like the spicy they can turn it way down. Me? I like it. And Henry's brings it. 

Service was quick without being overbearing and we ate very well for a very affordable price.
author: Dan S.

description:
They'll fix your cravings, give them a shot, but nothing to rave about.

I got the dumplings and the Hunan sweet and sour pork. The dumplings had great flavor and texture with lovely fresh ginger and pork, but unfortunately arrived swimming in "hot sauce" - a blend of sesame, chili, and peanut oil. So yes, unfortunately they were in a bath of oil which didn't keep me from eating them but I wouldn't order again.

The pork was great. Nothing too crazy, but the sauce was just the right consistency and avoided the bright red color that MSG-laden places tend to have. The breading was pleasantly light and crisp and I left a full customer.

It's a great place if you need a Chinese fix, you just won't be bragging about this place to your friends.
author: Ian H.

description: I ordered combination fried rice and it took a while to come out. Other than that the food is pretty decent. Not sure if I'd come back though. The place is pretty big. Despite that though you have to arrive pretty early because there's always a line.
author: Rachel P.

description: I ate here yesterday after an absence of about 35 years.  I used to come to the Kearny Street hole-in-the-wall every day, when I was an office drudge in 1979-81, for the smoked ham rice plate and onion cake.  They were the best part of my day back then, and this remains one of my favorite meals in memory.  For old time's sake, I ordered these.  While the rice plate is still good, it didn't seem as delicious as in the old days.  The service was excellent, considering the much larger size of the place, but it has grown impersonal with the frosty hostess as gatekeeper.  In 1980, at the old place, two thieves stole my wallet out of my purse during lunch, and the cashier could not have been more helpful.  I think I paid for my lunch the next time I came in.  I don't know if Mr. Chung is still the owner, but I missed the warmth of Kearny Street during yesterday's visit.
author: Lemora M.

description: This place is truly amazing. My family and I have been coming here for years and we are always satisfied with our order. We get the Diana Special (meat pie), Chinese chicken salad, string beans and chicken, and Henry's special.
author: Alexander J.

description:
I've been coming to Hunan since the first counter location opened on Kearney St., and was delighted when it opened the new locations on Sansome and Natoma.  The food is consistently GREAT, the service friendly, and it was this restaurant that started the national craze for hot and spicy Chinese back in the '70s.  Keep up the good work, and I'll definitely be back for more next time I'm up in SF!

PS to cold and allergy sufferers:  a bowl of Hot & Sour Soup is your best remedy!
author: Mike G.

description: I've never had a bad experience here.  The Diana's Meat Pie is really good and so large that  I always take leftovers to go. I always go during "off" hours and avoid peak times as they tend to get very busy.
author: Jan M.

description:
Let's be clear, this is a Chinese restaurant called Henry's. They aren't aiming for authenticity, they aren't going for class. All these complaints about oil miss the whole point.

This is where you go when you want to get some delicious American-Chinese food at stellar prices. The dumplings were $4, the entrees where between $7-$9. You aren't going to be able to buy enough food for Lunch and Dinner anywhere else in the Financial District for these prices. Bring the whole office, do family style, enjoy the fried rice and orange chicken like you are still in college and don't even know what the word "metabolism" means. 

Word to the wise, finishing a meal here could destroy your productivity for the rest of the day. Food comas are real.
author: Jake B.

description:
I came here today on a lunch reservation with coworkers to welcome a new employee to or team. The service was timely and efficient, and my coworkers were all satisfied with the food. The menu has many choices, and I appreciated that, according to so many other Yelp reviewers, they could be accommodating of gluten-free dietary needs. The key word is "could."

I got glutened. I am ill. It was not anyone's fault per se, but nevertheless I cannot recommend their restaurants to other people who cannot have gluten.

When I placed my order, I asked whether a certain dish could be made GF and the waiter said that it could. He said, "no soy sauce or black bean sauce, right?" And I said that i assumed that was the case unless they used wheat-free soy sauce. He said, "no problem."

The problem was realizing that I needed more veggies with my meal. I hadn't ordered any of my own and the Henry's Special was mostly protein, which is normally a huge plus. I asked him if the string beans we already had on the table were safe for me to eat. He said yes. I then ate about 2 cups of green beans. I was putting a bean in my mouth when the waiter came over with a plate of green beans for our table. For me.  He thought I had asked for a new order of GF green beans and told me at that point that the green beans on the table had soy sauce on them. I was crushed but knew it was a miscommunication.

Maybe this location isn't as good as the others about making sure gluten free diners can dine safely.

Be extra careful if you do decide to risk coming here.
author: Patricia D.

description: Best Chinese food I could ever have at a restaurant!! Tastes just like my mom's and grandmother's cooking!! The dumplings are to die for and the place has excellent service. I come all the time!! You haven't lived until you've tried Henry's Hunan!!
author: Addy Belle J.

description:
Well, Henry's was once a great Chinese restaurant here in the city. I think they have gotten too big for their britches and have gotten somewhat arrogant as well.

It is not the same Henry's that I visited 2 years ago. Portions are now skimpy.
I ordered kung pao chicken and got no chicken, so the dish should be called "kung pao onions".

This place has gone downhill!
author: James W.

description:
I came here yesterday for the lunch special and ended up pulling a shard of metal out of my mouth. It appeared to be from a cooking instrument of some sort and probably would have required surgery if I had swallowed it. I let the host know about it and she brought it to the kitchen, however I was surprised that they didn't offer to pay for my unfinished $8 plate. 

Another reviewer noted

I've been here probably 10 times and this was my first brush with death, so I gave a star back.
author: Andrew W.

description: Nothing fancy. Kinda old and boring Chinese food. Good enough for the late night beer hangover.
author: Kim L.

description:
Been coming here for around three years because a few co workers like it. Not entirely sure why... The food is very oily and salty - tastes like they reuse oil. The dishes are very inconsistent, especially their hot and sour soup. I had their chow mein once - and that was enough for me. Had a terrible burnt overtone that won't leave my flavor memory. 

We went today to celebrate one of our coworkers moving on to new opportunities. Since he was the last remaining patron of this place - the rest of us will surely be moving on to new culinary opportunities.
author: Tony A.

description: It was ok, crowded but food was delivered very fast despite of it. Food was just ok, like something I could have made but the service was great. Ill substitute ok or bad food for great service anyday.
author: Joe B.

description: I arrived at the restaurant at 12:55 pm Monday and the restaurant was not busy. I had been waiting for 45 minutes for my Kung Pao chicken over rice...still no food! I don't have two hours to spend on lunch. You guys just wasted my precious time. Can you imagine 45 minutes later, no food? I was furious but nobody really cared.  I asked the wait staff about it and no one knew what's going on. The waiter who took my order was helpless and the waitresses were equally clueless. They walked past my table many times and nobody even checked on my order.  When a customer has been sitting at a table for 45 minutes with no food. What does that mean to you? Your job is to wait tables. Nobody offered me any solution after a 45-minute wait.  At the end, I decided to just leave without my order because it was taking way too long. I've been a regular customer for many years but I don't think I will return ever again. Really not happy with your service today. You're taking your customers for granted.
author: Ron L.

description: I imagine Henry's is about as close to a "chop suey" house from the 1800s as you'll find in modern SF. The food was fast and cheap and there was a lot of it. The flavors were intense and on the salty and spicier side of the pallet. Portions are large and served "family" style. Like most Chinese restaurants, their menu is gigantic and you can probably find something for every one.  They even have a bunch of Americanized specials that I saw quite a few mandarin as a first language customers ordering. The staff was awesome, my server was Jody and she really made the evening an effortless success. I'll definately be back.
author: William T.

description:
After much soul-searching and mountaintop-sitting, I decided to lift my rating for Henry's Hunan to four stars. Yes, I know it's a controversial upgrade, and I am willing to take the slings and arrows of those unfortunate snobs who have dismissed this place for lent. What tipped me over was an unexpected dish, the $8.75 Polish Sausage Hunan Style - perhaps the most inauthentic concoction ever served in a Chinese restaurant. Who cares? It's greasy good in a Top Dog meets Yank Sing sorta way. Know what I'm sayin'? 

Well, we already know the $6.95 Diana's Meat Pie is about as Chinese as Charlie Chan in an opium den. It's one of the best tostadas you could possibly have outside of the Mission, although I have to remember to pick up some salsa from Taco Del Mar across the street the next time. Between Henry, Howard and Marty having their namesake specials, I was starting to think this was the West Coast outpost for Katz's Delicatessen, but alas, I think they're mostly hotter-than-the-hinges-in-hell kung pao dishes.

Regardless, I just couldn't sleep tonight until I gave Henry's the extra star for their anything-for-a-buck sorta-Hunan dishes. Sure, it ain't David Chang. It ain't even Charlie Chan. Henry's Hunan is like the Kathy Griffin of Chinese restaurants. 

FOOD - 4 stars...yes, Sophie didn't have a tougher choice than having the Polish Sausage over Diana's Tostada Greasepool...I mean, Meat Pie 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...well, it still needs a few more gongs 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...getting better, not sure why 
TOTAL - 4 stars...this is not a Polish joke
author: Ed U.

description:
Recently came to lunch here with a couple co-workers. We ordered a whole mess of food and I thought it was decent Chinese food. We got the pork fried rice, hot sour soup, chicken salad, hunan velvet chicken, dry-sauteed string beans, and henry's special. 

I thoroughly enjoyed the chicken salad but I thought everything else was decent. It was all a good deal though for a feast! All that for $65 including tip. :)
author: Joyce M.

description: Get the kung pao.  They even have kung pao pork.  It's really good.  Most of the other disheds include carrot, which I don't like.
author: David B.

description:
I have been going to Henry's Hunan for over 15 years now and am just getting around to writing a review.  Delinquent, I realize.  But this place is excellent.  My friends and I try to hit it up about once a month for lunch during the week and it always delivers.  I recommend going at 11:45 or 1:00 to avoid the rush and some long wait times, but if you have a small group of 2-4, you can usually get seated rather quickly. 

My favorites include the Henry's Special, Kung Pao Shrimp, Five Spiced Bean Curd, chow mein and hot & sour soup.  Great dishes, pretty fast service and a good atmosphere for a large windowless room.

I have been to all of the other locations as well and this one is my favorite.
author: Garrett D.

description: Tony Hiss in the 1970's in New Yorker Magazine called this the "Best Chinese Restaurant in the World".  Not an overstatement.
author: Diane D.

description:
I love Henry's Hunan. 

We took the ferry to town just to have lunch here. And it was every bit as good as I remember, even better it's inexpensive. If you like spicy food, this is your place. Not fancy, not flashy. Packed every time we've been here. It's all about the food here. Oh Henry, you like to bring the noise. Things can get hot up in here. My wife likes to get things jacked up and I'm amazed with the way my little lady can still put it away. She had the Henry's special of shrimp, scallops, chicken and veggies in a scorching hot sauce. I wimped out with the far milder Henry's shredded pork, with spinach, eggs and mushrooms. Mine was good, hers was better. Lesson learned, get it jacked up. 

Henry's is a must stop for me when I'm in the area, so much that I can plan an afternoon around it. I'll do that for the best Asian cuisine I've ever had. 

Hello Henry, is Chicago in your delivery area?
author: Dan G.

description:
Go to location for Co-Worker lunches. Service and wait time vary, sometimes we get a seat immediately other times we have to wait for 15 or 20 minutes. Food quality is pretty good, though sometimes we have been left waiting at a table because they have forgotten an order or just neglected to ever server us. 

The food is decent and you know what to expect.
author: Matt K.

description: Fantastic and affordable! Make sure to try Henry's specialty items on the menu. The dumplings are top notch as well! Will definitely go back.
author: Neill S.

description:
Food is very good. I don't understand all the negative reviews. But I will say the new hostess has either got to go or needs some kind of training. She is rude and unfriendly. When I asked to sit at a particular table she seemed very put off by my request. When I asked her if there was a problem she just stared at me and grudgingly let me sit at the table of my choice. It was not crowded and there were many open tables. Previous hosts and hostesses were always very friendly and made me feel welcome. I do not go here much anymore and she is the reason. I love the food.
P.S. Rest of wait staff is very friendly and gracious.
author: Bob P.

description: The food here is very oily and salty. The dishes pretty much fall into two categories: very salty and a little spicy and just very salty. I've been there a few times for large group outings. Oh yah, that's the one redeeming characteristic of the joint -- they accommodate large groups. Where else can you get 15 people to sit at one giant round table? Even the fast food joint Ming's one block away has better food.
author: Alice W.

description:
RUDE, RUDE waiter/bus boy!  Food quality has dropped over the years!  Avoid this location at all cost.  Go to the other locations at like Bryant St or Church St.
     I've been going to this location for 16 years.  Our office was across the street I'd go with my co-workers once a week for at least 8-9 years until we moved offices.  I'd also take family from out of town periodically on the weekends.  I go less often now to this location, maybe once a year after a meeting at the office.  I usually order take out from the location on Bryant street on my way home.
    I had family from Los Angeles come for the weekend and I was excited to introduce them to Henry's Hunan.  So I've noticed that the quality at this location has diminished.  We ordered Hot and Sour Chicken, Marty Special and Curry Chicken.  All three dishes seemed to be a lot greasier than I remember, like extra greasy.  The chicken had a few pieces that were rubbery, the dumpling seem a bit hard/stale.  Two of the 5 tea cups were dirty.  My chopsticks had old food that seemed to be fused on it.  And the forks probably have never been changed they were misshapen and look like the same one from 16 years ago. 
    So here's the worst service I've ever experienced in my 20+ years of eating out.  We're finishing eating, I get up to ask for the check so my family from Los Angeles doesn't beat me it.  I pay at the front via credit card and leave $0 tip since on the credit.  I always always leave the tip in cash, since I figured if the tip is paid via the credit card the waiter has to report that exact amount on their taxes etc, and if I leave cash they can report what ever they want.  
    Anyway, I always leave a minimum of 15%-20% even on bad service.  I go back to sit down with my wife and family from out of town. We are still chatting and they're drinking their tea.  A minute or two passes when the bus boy comes up and scans the table, I figured he is going to take the empty plates or offer us refills on the tea or water, but no he interrupts our chat to tell me "Tip's not included" I'm a bit confused for a second and respond with "Oh, yeah I know"  he just nods and repeats the exact same thing 3X!!!! "Tip's not included" I reply "I know" each time more and more bothered at his insinuation that I'm gonna stiff them on the tip in front of my wife guest.  I went up to the owner to complain which I never never have done.  I told her that I've frequented that location for over 16 years and I always leave the tip in cash and that I've never had something like that happen.  She said sorry, and said she would tell him.  
   So I made a yelp account just to post this long post about my experience, since it's been bothering me since Friday.  The waiter/bus boy has been there for many years and I don't expect him to recognize me since I went less and less frequently but man was he rude and out of line.  Am I over reacting?  I've just never been confronted by an employee and especially in front of family and guest.  So Rude.  I'm debating on whether or not to post my story on my YouTube channel with 500k subscribers.  An apology from the waiter or a formal apology from the Owner would be nice.

btw, yes I still left a 15% tip even after that experience.
author: Juan P.

description:
The place is always crowdy, so if one needs to go along with big group, plan ahead.
Service isn't really slow, but can be frustrating if few items turn early and others don't. Taste wise some of the items are incredible, but didn't explore as I knew what I wanted.. Go for Curry chicken if one wants little spicy food. Overall a good alternative for Chinese food in the area.
author: Srikant D.

description:
So this review is only for this location (I haven't tried the other ones).  The place gets seriously packed for lunch, so the best time to come is at opening (11:30) or around 1pm if your schedule is flexible enough.

My favorite dishes are the Hot and Sour Chicken, Curry Chicken, and Sauteed Eggplant.  Fantastic.  I'd eat here every day if I worked close enough.
author: G G.

description:
It was very unplanned that I get to try this place. To be honest, it was a Beautiful unplanned disappointment, because their next door neighbor (same owners i heard) was Closed. SO was closed.

My girl friend and I drove all the way from San jose to SF for So..and ended up here...

It was great....I loved every kind of dish we got.

Prices were decent...and the servings were HUGE.

I highly recommend the Spicy Ham.
I also loved the Glass Noodles.
The Chicken Wings were also BOMB. Very tasty.
The dumplings as appetizers were also amazing...They were definitely homemade.

The -1 star was because the service was pretty LONG.

I would definitely go back.. 

No MSG in this place...
author: Monica H.

description:
Strange they don't have Hunan Beef or Hunan Chicken on the menu. They do have something called Hunan Velvet Chicken, which is like Kung Pao Chicken without the peanuts or the spiciness. It is pretty good.

Granted most other dishes are okay (garlic chicken, green beans, soft tofu, etc.), but after awhile they all started to look and taste the same...with much black bean sauce. They claimed they don't use MSG, but I do like my MSG tbh.

However, the thing that got to me was the waiter letting out a small laugh, saying "nice try" for ordering Hunan Beef or Hunan Chicken. Whaa? Oh no you diint! A generous four stars.
author: Peter L.

description:
Ok, so it (may or) may not exactly be authentic Chinese cuisine but who cares ? I have not met a single dish I didn't like here on this Natoma St branch of this mini chain (all of 4 outlets strong, and within a few miles of each other). 

I am not an authority on Chinese cuisine but am told that the dishes from the Hunan province/area in China are usually on the spicier side. That said, the hot and spicy Kung-pao chicken, Chicken with string-beans in black bean sauce, and the generous helpings of steamed rice are always spot on whenever I am in a "Need for Heat". 

I have always loved the chicken chowmein, the kung-pao shrimp (though I still maintain it's chicken based cousin is way better) and all the other dishes I've had but can't remember (not that reciting the whole menu here is gonna help anyone). The onion pancake is ok and I have to admit I have had better potstickers --- though it was still pretty decent (no complaints actually). 

The service may be a bit wanting during the peak lunch hours what with all the hungry office-goers of SOMA and neighboring Financial District migrating south in droves but I can live with that. As someone rightly pointed out, they might be faster with the check than with checking to see if you needed anything else. 

Make sure to get there before noon (I usually aimed for 11:45am) to beat the hungry hordes on a working day. 

A note about the price : although the entrees are priced at around the '$$' mark, the portions are generous and since they are served family style, a group of four can easily share two entrees with steamed rice for a per-person cost that pulls it down to the "$" price range (if you're a voracious viking, all bets are off) .

(I hate those slippery waxed chopsticks they have in most restaurants --- gimme the wooden disposables anyday!!!)
author: Umesh T.

description:
I never received my food because I was tired of waiting for them to bring out anything, even appetizers, after waiting for ~55 minutes. 

When placing the order, I was told it would be less than 30 minutes.  I proceeded to watch other people come in later, be seated and order later, and receive food before us.  They seemed like regulars.  

We ordered appetizers and main courses to share, and outside of glasses of water, nothing came.  I asked after waiting for 45 minutes when the food would arrive.  I was told 3-4 minutes.  After waiting ~55 minutes, that was enough and we went to a real restaurant.
author: Peter K.

description:
I joined a group of locals for lunch and I really liked it! 

We arrived early to beat the lunch rush.  There were 7 of us and we ordered 5 meals and still had leftovers.  The food was nice&hot and very flavorful.  The spicy plates weren't too spicy that you couldn't enjoy your meal.  That was a plus.  

I recommend this place and will def try to eat here on my next trip out to San Fran.
author: Elle G.

description:
These guys have one of the best hot & sour soups around.  Perfectly hot & perfectly sour!  Another fav is their chow mein.  An indication for great chow mein is a fire hot wok that can't be replicated anywhere else.  These guys have got it!  

Yumm to smoky flavored just about anything they fry up...the wok is the key!
author: Wina K.

description: I went here a year ago. It was moderate food. Not the best service ever. Just wanted to review cause I just saw it was on the page. Decent food. Will do in a pinch.
author: Laird Z.

description:
I had no idea this place existed, I rarely ever go out to buy Chinese food but so glad to have found this place. I love Hunan food, known for its liberal use of chili peppers, garlic and occasional use of black bean sauce. All my favorites!

My coworkers and I came here for lunch, we made a reservation for 14 and they had no problem accommodating us (even when 14 turned into 10). When we arrived, our table was ready. We ordered a bunch of different dishes to eat family style (onion pancakes, bean curd, string beans, eggplant, veggie chow mein, harvest pork, etc). All of the dishes are vibrant, generous portions of chili peppers (you can ask for it to be mild), and rich in flavor. My favorites were the harvest pork, bean curd and onion pancakes. The only dish that fell short for me was the veggie chow mein - it tasted like electricity. Yes, you read that right. After telling my fellow guests that, they tried another bite and agreed. It's not a burnt taste, it's a gasoline-like taste. 

We ended up being filled to the brim, spent approx $12/person including tax and tip and had so much food leftover that we could feed maybe 3 other people. It was cheap, delicious and a good lunch. Thank you for taking good care of us Henry Hunan! I will definitely be back and I must try the famous meat pie next time.
author: Stella C.

description: Great Hunan food in the financial district and close to Moscone Convention Center. If you like spicy food, you are going to love this place. Just make sure to ask for a glass of water. Pretty authentic and really good food.
author: Peter K.

description: Service is pretty bad, even for Chinese standards and I've been to mainland China too. Probably took about 10 minutes to flag down a waiter who seemed to be preoccupied with checking his phone for what was probably a Chinese version of Tinder. Food finally came out and it was non stop. They probably wanted us out of there.
author: John B.

description: After I finish my plate. I notice that it was mostly onions and bell peppers on my vs the sweet and sour chicken I order. It taste good.
author: Gabriel G.

description: This place is a great place to get flavor packed delicious food. I've actually been craving it since I went with my boyfriend and our neighbor. He suggested it and I'm so grateful he did. We have been wanting to go back. The fish in chili sauce and the beef with string beans were amazingly tender. The meat pie thing that they have was also full of flavor! This is a must go back type of place.
author: Marlene T.

description: Just now came for food. No hot tea. No chopsticks. I asked for chopsticks but this guys told me we give only to Americans . What I will do next is to find some witness from nearby table and see what I can do for this humiliation. We had to leave without ordering. We really liked the food and came from fremont driving 40 miles. I will make sure someone pay for my gas and time
author: Rajib B.

description:
Even the rice was 5 . Seriously, best rice I've ever had.
Sweet and Sour Chicken was delicious.
And wait staff: amazing
author: Kat Z.

description: Friendly service, and excellent food. Love their spicy cod, and it's crispy and actually spicy. Kung pao chicken is also really good. They also make a mean green onion pancake. A lot of their stuff is spicy, which is right up my alley. This place is great. Side note: atmosphere is meh, and could use some updating. Takes away from the experience because it kind of feels like you're eating in a dark warehouse.
author: Sal K.

description: I didn't get food poisoning, which was great, but that doesn't mean the food was good. I got Orange Chicken and white rice. The chicken was super bland, definitely more on the sweet side. I had to add soy sauce to make it palatable. The rice was super mushy. I couldn't finish it, which is unfortunate since I paid like 13 bucks for it.
author: Jess W.

description: Gold standard. Had excellent kung pao chicken for takeout while staying at a nearby hotel - heat and flavor balanced in that perfect way that lights your mouth afire but keeps you plunging back.
author: Jason M.

description: We were always big fans of the Sansome Street location (we had our wedding reception there!).  This location is our go-to location when we have time before an SF Giants game.  I think this place is super busy for a weekday lunch but a weeknight or a Saturday visit is the best time.  We stuck with our typical Diana's meat pie and dumplings and made sure to have the chicken salad.  If it is two of us again, we may drop the dumplings.
author: Glenn L.

description:
One of my friend's order never came (which was kind of okay since we were eating family-style). The server came and asked me in an awkward whisper if I wanted rice. I asked the group. They all said no and I did too. Ten minutes later a small bowl of rice is placed before me. 

The Mongolian Beef and Sweet & Sour Chicken were both good though.
author: Jennifer P.

description: I dont order everything from Henery's but that SHRIMP FRIED RICE IS SLAMMING!
author: Corey G.

description:
Spicy, Salty, MSG!  Sometimes you're in the mood for just that.  :)  That's when you go to Henry's!  Be warned, DO NOT go to the one on Sacramento St if the above is what you're after... it's NOT the same!  

Favorite must haves:
meat pie
smoked ham and green beans
mongolian beef

Another warning:  This is NOT "authentic"!!!  For peets sake, it's GOOD and tasty, and that's what this game is all about!!!
author: Jennifer H.

description: I went to this place many times. Consistently good food with very bad customer service. I will only go there if I am ready to wait. Around 20min to get the table in peak hours and roughly 30 min to get the order.
author: Gopal G.

description:
I'm scratching my head at this place, especially given the reviews. After hearing that this is the 'best Chinese' from 2 coworkers, I decided to have a business lunch there. I went through the back and it's definitely much bigger than I thought given the unassuming storefront, which turned out to be storeback.

I had moo shoo pork and my business colleague had the chow mein. The place has a large menu and was reasonably priced, but we both thought the food was lackluster. Neither finished our meals.

I reserved judgement and didn't post a review since I thought it was maybe the dish and I was comparing it to one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in NYC. Well, this week someone picked up takeout from here for me as I had a lunch conference call. Note that I didn't pick the item but she had to have a stack of paper towels underneath the paper bag since the grease was oozing out of the Chinese food container. She had spare towels just to put the container on as well. After dishing it out onto the thick paper plate, I had only a handful of bites before I determined that there was nothing tasty about the dish.

As I was throwing away the plate, I realized that the grease had seeped through the thick paper plate and put a full dose of greasy film onto the desk. I'd be shitting and sweating grease me thinks if I actually did finish that dish.
author: Trang H.

description:
Great Chinese food in downtown SF!

The place is located near an alley and definitely looks like an authentic Chinese restaurant.

We ordered the orange chicken, beef spinach egg, meat pie, and squid. The dishes were all amazing but I would recommend getting the beef spinach egg and meat pie.

The meat pie is literally two pieces of crisp friend Chinese style pancakes filled with minced beef and lettuce. The beef spinach egg is the perfect combination and balance of flavors. The restaurants sauce tops it off.

The restaurant also offers brown or white rice. Service was friendly but some waiters don't speak English that fluently. Overall great place for Chinese food!
author: Stephen C.

description: This is by far the worse customer service I've received in the ENTIRE city... realistically, in my entire life.  Went there around 12:30pm today and ordered the beef stew noodle soup with no onions. When my order came, there were onions.  Mistakes happens, I understand... I told the sever to take it back since I requested no onions. She said, "You take it out."  I explained to her that I was allergic and I can't eat onions.
