She had the audacity to say, "Just take out" then she walked away. I tried to get the manager, but I wasn't able to flag anyone down for the next couple of minutes. I got tired of waiting and begrudgingly tried to remove the onions. Part of me hoped that I'd fall on the floor with respiratory problems.. but they'd probably shove me under the table.  I ate part of the meal and had to ask for the check when I started breaking out in hives.  It's a shame that you give Chinese restaurants a bad reputation. I will NEVER come back.
author: J T.

description: Really lovely experience! Everything was so fresh and tender! Prices are reasonable and portions are hearty. This is my new Chinese go to.
author: Disco B.

description: I love that this place is unchanged from when I moved to the bay 25+ years ago. This is by far the spiciest hunan place I've tried outside of China. It's not for the faint of heart, but it's oh so yummy! It has some strange menu additions that stray from traditional hunan like Diana's Special Meat Pie, I don't know quite how to describe this dish except it's delicious! Great for vegetarians as well with wonderful firm spicy tofu that even meat eaters will like! I hope this place never changes!
author: Jordan M.

description:
I should have known from all the white people here that this was going to be a lousy lousy experience. This very Americanized pseudo-Chinese food is C.R. to the A. P. The kong-pao beef, possibly the worst I've ever had in the world, is just a goopy mess of what looks to be beef surrounded by other non-Chinese ingredients. 

How has this place been open since 1974?
author: James S.

description:
Ew ew ew ew ew. I came here with 2 girlfriends after an event at 111 Minna. We were finally seated after wandering around wondering if the host stand is at their second entrance (it's not).

Once seated they gave us menus that smelled like hot plastic. It was very strong, but we decided perhaps they are new so oh well, it's just menus. 

We got veggie spring rolls, chicken chow mein, Orange Chicken and veggie Lo Mein. 

The spring rolls had no flavor--they just tasted of hot oil. 

The orange chicken was disgusting. The sauce would web like hot cheese when you went to scoop up a portion. Seriously? What is in that sauce? I have never seen orange chicken that had sauce that was stringy and carried a syrupy line all over the table. 

The Veggie Lo Mein was too spicy hot for our friend even though she requested no spice. 

We had terrible service and had to hunt down the waiter for our check. 

Save your time, money and appetite for a place with higher quality food and customer service.
author: Desiree P.

description:
My first time eating here was back in 2003 or 2004; I had eaten at another location before, but this one has been my go-to for years (same for many ex-coworkers of mine). 

Okay, so I have had a number of the items on the menu and have liked each and every one of them, with a special love for the dumplings, Marty's Special, and the Hunan house bean curd. I love my tofu and Henry's makes some awesome tofu dishes with just the right level of heat. The chicken fried rice is solid, as are the kung pao chicken and the chicken with black bean sauce plates. And one of my old favorites is the noodles w/pork meat sauce and Hunan special sauce...yummylicious.

The service isn't always great, but that doesn't bother me. I mean seriously, I see some hole in the wall places get high marks and we know how terrible the service is at those spots, yet the food is amazing so it gets a pass fine. I never remember the name of the gentleman who cashes people out, but he has always been great and remembers names like a human rolodex. 

This is the restaurant I missed the most when I moved away to Seattle for a spell. I'd visit SF and swing by Henry's for some grub and it always hits the spot. Plus, Chinese/Hunan food in Seattle is TERRIBLE, with the exception of O'Asian. That wasn't nice of me, so I will end this review and go sit in the corner.
author: Karim V.

description:
Wow, San Franciscans are a bitchy bunch when it comes to their Chinese food.

Sure Henry's Hunan isn't the best place for Chinese food in a city where there are probably 200 Chinese food restaurants within a 5-mile radius of Union Square.  But coming from Chicago, where a trip to our Chinatown (1/8th the size of San Francisco's) ranges from 4-star Hunan & Schezwan dining to Fear Factor-style dives, Henry's Hunan isn't too bad.

It's also a retreat from the Moscone Center crowd which tends to only venture beyond a 2-block radius with the assistance of a local.  I found the place back in 1999 and have returned every year during MacWorld Expo.

I stay clear of iffy dishes and stick with the easy stuff.  And yes, in the harsh words of another reviewer, I'm part of the "non-Chinese pansies who don't have flame retardant tongues and stomachs" who like things bland and not spicy.  The portions are generous (even by my big-butt, Midwestern buffet eatin' standards), so skip the appetizers.
author: Robert S.

description: Dropped into this restaurant to grab takeout.  I ordered the Mushu Pork, which was freshly-made within about 10 minutes.  There was nothing particularly special about this dish, or the restaurant.  If you are craving Chinese food, then this is a great place to go.  However, I wouldn't go too far out of my way to come.  It's conveniently located around the corner from my office for easy access!
author: Andrew H.

description: Been here twice and food was okay. Price was reasonable. I would come back again. Also, I love their specials on weekdays. My favorite so far is the kung pao chicken over rice.
author: Elaine C.

description:
We popped in here while on vacation in San Fran due to a recommendation. 

The service is poor. If I worked near here, despite the price, I'd be hesitant to go because the service is slow, slow, slow. We were sat for quite awhile before anyone showed up to take our drink order, and then they brought our drinks and disappeared again. We were probably there 30 minutes before they took our order. For us, on vacation, worn out from a morning of site seeing, no big deal. For others? That could really suck.

We got the Spring Rolls, the vegetable chow mein, and the pork kung pao. Everything was incredible. The spring rolls were awesome. Hot, crispy, with super fresh veggies inside. The vegetable chow mein was loaded with fresh, perfectly pan fried veggies, gooey noodles, and a super yummy sauce. And the Pork Kung Pao. Crazy good. Crazy spicy. We absolutely loved it. It was some of the very best Chinese we've had. 

We were never asked how we were, if we liked it, if we wanted anything else, nothing. Simply presented with the check. I asked for a Coke, to extinguish the flames, and the waiter seemed put out. Went and got my Coke, modified our check, and disappeared. 

We paid up front, enjoyed the made right there fortune cookies, and left.

If we are in the area again? I think I'd place an order to go. The food was solid (actually, to us, deserved a 5), the service just sucked.
author: Mindy W.

description:
Reasonably priced lunch spot with indoor seating - good for downtown SF. You can have a delicious meal for about $10. We ordered the hot and sour soup and mu shu - I highly recommend both. 

The restaurant is huge, so get there around noon and you'll be fine.
author: Analisa S.

description: such a mediocre Chinese restaurant, just slightly better than Fang's. Bearing the same name, the one on Bryant is better( although the waiting is unbearable...)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I decided to try Henry's on the basis of its (mixed) Yelp reviews. It turns out, Henry does a decent job. It was reasonably priced (for San Francisco), spicy enough for me, clean, and fast. That last bit may have to do with the timing--I can't seem to shake Chicago time, so my 6pm dinner felt like 8pm--and the BART strike now paralyzing the city.

It's hard to decide whether to give 3 or 4 stars. I mean, the food wasn't particularly good or bad, and it wasn't particularly expensive or cheap. It was, however, exactly what I wanted at the time. So, benefit of the doubt; and a recommendation.
author: David B.

description:
If you're looking for some life-altering chinese food while you're in San Fran, you must go to Henry's Hunan.  All you need are four items (Broccoli Beef, Henry's Special (mild), Shrimp fried rice and Chicken Chow-Mein. Shit, I forgot the dumplings. Make that five items...May is the fifth month...see PERFECT!!

I've come here for celebrations like birthdays and such and everyone is always happy to see me and my crew and every time I bring in out of town guests, they agree with me that it's some of the best Chinese food they've ever had in their life.  I drive from Vallejo into the city on some occasions...JUST to eat here.  Yes, it's that good.  

I could really eat here every day.  It's consistently good and clean and just what I need in my life.  I really need them to move into the north/east bay...just for me!!
author: Charmayne Y.

description: This place was pretty good, but the hunt for really good Chinese food nearby continues.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've been eating at Henry's Hunan in its various locations for 40 years.  I'm never disappointed.  Service is fast and efficient.  Love the food including Harvest Pork, Henry's Special, Hot and Sour Soup and Onion Cakes.  All full of flavor.

Henry's is a no-nonsense restaurant that does its job consistently well.
author: Bill H.

description: I have been a customer at Henry's Hunan since the days when Henry himself was alive. He only had one small "Hole in the Wall" location on Kearny Street. Cooking area was in open view. Once can sit and watch their food being made. It was as good as it could get and all very affordable. That location is long gone but I am glad they opened up all these new locations. I have been to almost all the locations but the Natoma location is most convenient for me.  Almost all the items are good but I love Marty special.  Diced Chicken is my fav for lunch. It is served quickly and the price is just right. Service is okay and cleanliness can be improved. However, if food is your passion, this is the place.
author: Edward N.

description:
Another regular spot for lunch downtown. All of their specials are good; kung pao chicken, curry chicken, beef with bean curd and even their fried rice. Throw some of their signature spicy oil on your dish and that's the cherry on top.

Beat the wait, come early before noon or wait till after the lunch rush.
author: Laxme G.

description:
Back in the day when I worked at a funky publishing house, Henry's was our stomping grounds.  The best bang for the buck for lunch. 

I was so looking forward to eating good food, drinking cold beer and watching some campy movies.  At the least the beer was cold.  The food was poor... to bad.  maybe it our choice in dishes... clearly we were not too imaginative

Spring roll --okay

Sweet and Sour-- dry 

Kung pao chicken--- not enough sauce, dry and just boring

braised short ribs-- way too many onions, the cute little ribs were good, sauce good.
I am not going back,  Now I off to try So in Soma--- I heard it was good fusion asian.  
No smilie face for you Henry!  :-(
author: Princess P.

description:
I rarely write reviews, but I needed to tell everyone about this place. My boyfriend and I have visited the North Beach location. Wow.
We had a late lunch- the dry noodles with yellow curry and the smoked pork with rice. Uh-mazing.
I don't really like Chinese food, but this is GOOD. We were so delighted with it.
And the service was really good- the chef even came to our table to check in. So nice of him!
All in all, I'll be there soon. Food porn.
author: Andreea C.

description:
Ok so other people rated this place really low, but I totally disagree. It's so yummy! It's also super cool because it is right next to 111 Minna, yay! 

Tonight we ordered:

Green Beans w/ Bean Curd
Garlic Chicken
Hot and Sour Soup
Another soup w/ ear mushrooms (?)
Dumplings
Side of rice

Everything was super tasty and the portions were quite large. We ordered two SMALL soups, and they were definitely not small...more like large? We got several small bowls filled from each one, and they only cost $4.50! Cheap much? The Hot and Sour soup was especially good, and totally warmed me up from the freezing rain outside. 

Everything was great, and we'll definitely be back!
author: Sonya D.

description: Try beef pie, it's not a conventional northern Chinese beef pie, more like a Chinese-Mexian fusion, with lettuce and cheese in it, crunchy skin, I was surprised to have eaten this here, a must try.
author: Tian W.

description: This is one of the go-to lunch places for us whenever we have a large group of people including some vegetarians. Spicy cod was a must, they have a good selection of vegan dishes as well.
author: Min L.

description:
I can't believe I forgot to review this place!

Dining-in:
There is usually a line but it moves fast.
These folks know their clientele are business folk that need to be on their way.
Once you are seated the service is brisk but effective, there is no coddling here.
The food is typical chinese american fare with a certain something that really does separate it from the rest.
For example the fried rice- most fried rice dishes seem like they have been overcooked in soy sauce to me. Here the fried rice is different, some how a little lighter. It reminds me of the fried rice at Benihana. Mmm mmm good.
I love the dumplings and always order the Kung Pao.

Catering:
Excellent option for office lunches.
Timely delivery and budget friendly.
Fed 15 people for about $130.

Love this place!
author: Edi B.

description: The food is acceptable but the headache after consumption is not.  I don't know how much MSG they are using but an hour after I ate here, my head was throbbing.  Ugh.  Never again.
author: Ronita J.

description:
WHOA! These reviews are soo OFF! This is totally NOT awesome or authentic chinese food! I'm not sure how some reviewers are raving about this place as the best ever! The name should tell it all!

Service was def missing.  They came to took our order, served us one incorrect dish (got the hunan special instead of the orange chicken), never came back... except to give us the bill ! 

Here's what we tried:
*Shrimp fried rice - this was good, but any asian restaurant can make fried rice, can't they?
*Eggplant - flavorful sauce, actually one of the better dishes
*Smoked ham and string beans - Wayy too salty! String beans were not crunchy at all!  Ham was not tasty either..
*Hunan Special - bunch of stir fried seafood and veggies in a bland sauce
*Green onion pancakes - Where's the dipping sauce??? 
*Sauteed pork with bamboo shoots (i think this was kung pao pork??)  - Wayy too salty also!! 

If you're looking for average food, and you think most chinese food tastes the same, then I say go for it!  Especially if you're into sauteed dishes with generic sauces and spices.  If you're looking for authentic chinese cuisine, then head closer to Chinatown!! LOL
author: Tramy V.

description: I went here for lunch today with ex-coworkers. Been going to this restaurant as well as their restaurant on Montgomery since 1990. I will be honest and say I am habitual and always order the Henry's Special, Fish and Tofu, 33 and 23 respectively on the menu, I think, steamed rice and the pot stickers. I can't speak for the rest of the menu but these are delicious. Each of these less the pot stickers are about $9. Lunch for three with two sodas and tea for me with tip $48.
author: Philip C.

description:
A quality option for inexpensive lunch time dining.

If you plan to eat lunch here during the week, you'd best arrive by 11:45am. Get here at 12:01 and there's probably already a line. This is a great place to bring groups. They have some round tables toward the back that seat 6-10 and they hold those back for large groups even when there is a line of smaller parties waiting. So you can just show up with 6 people and walk right in.

Food is good. Not spectacular. Tea is fairly boring. They sell soft drinks by the can. Some of the sauces are a little heavy, drowning the meat or vegetables rather than accompanying them. The white rice isn't really sticky enough for chopsticks, which is frustrating. 

Your best approach is to come here with a large group, and order several different entrees. The round tables come with a lazy susan so everyone can share.

It's not a meal you're going to brag to your friends about. But you're probably in and out for about $12 a person, and for lunch in the city, that isn't a terrible result.
author: TJ P.

description:
The orange chicken is delicious here.  It doesn't taste like fake orange chicken, this is closer to traditional style with orange peel and lots of spicy peppers!  super tasty!

Also the chow mein is really good too!  This place is very under rated....
author: Shawn A.

description:
Wow, reading these reviews from folks that have never eaten real Hunan food, and for them to give a One or Two stars is cruel and hardly worth noting. 

Henry's Hunan is not a chow mein/fried rice, sweet & sour pork place.  If that's what you're seeking, you're at the wrong place.    

The  Hunan Food here is excellent and it's spicy for Western taste buds but only average spiciness compared to what you would get in China.  How spicy would you get in China?  On a scale of 1 to 10, this would be only a 3 to 4.  

My own complaint is that Henry's Hunan caters to Western people as their menu's are only written in English and not in Chinese characters, which is a real dis-service to Chinese people.  

BTW, our family started eating at their establishment when it was located on Kearny Street in Chinatown, and when they used to have Chinese menu's.  Years before James Beard wrote a column and put the Hunan Restaurant on the map.

Also, each of their four locations are operated and owned by different members of the family.  Marty Chung is the oldest son, owns & operates that location on Sansome Street off of Broadway.  Check out his place. 

If you want to try really hot   and spicy food, go to Z&Y on Jackson Street, in between Grant/Kearny.  That place will kill your taste buds and satisfy your hunger for hot
author: Kathy K.

description:
Go to Henry's Hunan once in a while. The foods are tasty, on the salty side, guess that it is understandable for most of the Chinese restaurant using MSG. The hot and spicy soup is not my cup of tea, just the combination of sourness and spicyness not my favorite but my friends from Taiwan love it. The spinach with chicken and eggs is our all time favorite and we order it every time we come here. We are kind of trying many different dishes and look for what we really like. Most of the dishes are good, a little bit salty mostly.

The charges are reasonable for restaurant in downtown area of SF.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Restaurant only about 1/2 full at 7:00 PM on a Tuesday night and service is slow as molasses. Are they slaughtering and plucking the chicken for my kung pao? Steamed dumplings are mediocre. I'm so hungry I could eat the whole order of five, but they're so bland, it's not even worth the calories. And I don't even count calories. It is cold and drafty, even though I am nowhere near the door. I haven't been here in about ten years, but I remember the good quality and service being much better. A middling experience at best, in a city rife with great Chinese food. And can we talk about SALT?? No reason to return here--especially with Fang around the corner.
author: Michele W.

description:
12.20.10

If you absolutely, positively need a fix of greasy Chinese food, then this place is for you.

Don't expect good, or quick service.  We waited 30 minutes before our food came out.  So if you go with someone, make sure they're a good conversationalist, or at least good to look at.
author: Jenny L.

description: Not the best place; my Chicken with string beans was more oily than I like. But we were the last ones in the restaurant and so, we probably just had an unusual experience.
author: Hari B.

description:
This particular Henry's Hunan location was one of my favorites when I worked in S.F.  I would gleefully make the trek for the Spicy Rock Cod which was always phenomenal.  I do not eat fish, as a rule, but I really enjoyed this dish.

Recently, the wife and I brought the girls into S.F. for a short visit.  I had to stop in here for dinner.  We...I say "we", but in truth..."I" ordered the Spicy Rock Cod.  I also ordered the Diana's Meat Pie.  The kids ordered the kung pao chicken and the mongolian beef.  The missus had a bit of a sore throat, so she wanted some soup...an order of hot and sour soup was placed as well.

Ahhh...the memories came rushing back me.  All the flavors were on point in each dish.  The meat pie was really good and a definite hit with my younger daughter who said, Dad, we should stop by here on the way home and get a couple of these 'to go"!"  The Spicy Rock Cod was as grand as I remember it being...did I mention that I do not typically eat fish?  Yes, it's that good.

We left there totally stuffed...and very pleased that I didn't have to shell out a ton of cash for dinner...which was quite unusual for a dinner for 4 in S.F. (I'm a cheapskate, I admit it.)

It goes without saying, but I'll definitely return to Henry's.
author: Doug J.

description:
I was so disappointed with my dish I felt compelled to Yelp it. 

My coworkers order here regular, so I decided to join them.  I asked my colleague what's good and he suggust the Kung Pao Chicken.  This  dish as generic and standard of a dish as possible for "Chinese" food.  How could ANYONE get this dish wrong. Well Henry Hunan manage to do it!


If I were Henry, I would simply just rename the dish to Kung Pao Onions.  When the dish is 80% onion and 20% chicken, how does it qualify as a chicken dish??   So my lunch was really rice and onions, flavored with chicken for $8-$9.

I was so embarrassed for this establishment I'd shut down the business if I were them.  But that's my opinion.
author: Hugh H.

description:
I stopped in with some friends on a chilly Sunday night. Henry's was not too busy so we gave it a shot, and I'm glad we did. 
    We started off with some hot soup, which was served with a cup of green tea. My benchmark of the quality of a Chinese restaurant is hot and sour soup, and I was not disappointed. It was hot, flavorful, and just spicy enough. For my main dish, I opted for the Mongolian beef, which also did not fail to deliver. The grilled veggies tasted fresh and were not too heavy and not at all greasy. The beef was cooked jut right. Like the soup our main plates were served family-style. All three dishes were prepared just as we'd asked. 
    The service was very friendly and quick. The restaurant itself was clean. 
     If you're in the neighborhood and in the mood for Chinese, Henry's definitely deserves a look.
author: Sal C.

description:
This a great spot for lunch downtown. There is only one dish I order: the kung pao chicken and a side of rice.

I've tried other dishes. The pot stickers with a special sauce is great. If I veer away from the kung pao it really isn't to my liking.

Go here for the kung pao and you won't regret it.
author: Jim B.

description:
Love this place for hunan cuisine. 
It is large restaurant in sizing. But because of popularity, you still have to wait at peak hours.
To accommodate crowd, chairs are very close to each other. Almost all dishes are good and should be tried. 
I requested many times about less salt but somehow I see that they never honored my request. I always find salt is at higher level.
Price is little above than average for Chinese food
author: Prasad D.

description: This place might look like a hole in the wall, but don't let that fool you.  This is the best Chinese I've had in a LONG time, and I'm so glad my boss took us here.  We let him order all the food, and I enjoyed every dish.    Diane's Meat pie is THE BEST!!! SO DELICIOUS.. Fried crunchy meaty goodness.  The green bean with meat sauce is also an excellent choice.  Will definitely come back here again!
author: Rob K.

description: I like the food at this restaurant, unfortunately the welcoming is awful.   I had a bad experience once, then a second time and today was the third time, all three times was the same person unprofessional behaviour:   the hostess.   I like to enjoy and respect my lunch time, to me is very important.   Unfortunately the hostess attitude is awful, she is rude, very rude, she has no manners, she doesn't respect the clientele, no greeting, no smile, no answer to questions.
author: J.A. V.

description: Thank you for your message Frank. No worries. The prices are just the sign of the times "and" the area. By no means does this affect how much I love your food! I didn't mean to deduct stars off of your 5 star food.  Trust me, I can't and won't stay away. As a matter of fact I may pop in today. I hear there's a Tuesday special...Hot & Sour Chicken over rice. If that's the case I'm heading over....Also I have updated my rating to reflect what I actually do think of the food AND your outreach to your customers.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Dumplings and meat pie.  If you have never been to Henry's then start with these two starters.  If you go at lunch (noon) be prepared to wait in line and then wait a bit more for the food to arrive.  In the end, you tummy will thank you for a great lunch!
author: Robert H.

description:
I have been coming here for lunch for over 10 years.  I really like it because many of the people recognize me and treat me like a valued customer.   I've introduced the place to lots of my friends and they love it now too.

My favorites are:  the meat sauce noodles; the Liling noodles; the tofu beef rice and chicken with garlic and vegetable rice plates.  I also like the Diana's meat pies every now and then.

Big portions, good prices, friendly service and also clean.  Great location for me - just off 2nd a little past Mission.
author: Evelyn L.

description:
Henry's has overall decent Chinese food if you're downtown with non-Chinese people and want a conveniently located place to go with a nice variety of dishes.

I won't say it's the best because there are places in Chinatown which will always be better (perhaps it's a little less "authentic" because it caters to mostly non-Chinese clientele who prefer not to eat MSG which is perfectly innocuous as far as seasonings go but some fear it like bird flu).  But, that being said at least it's not some fusion restaurant! =)

Whenever I go with friends/coworkers we usually grab an appetizer and a few lunch specials which are more than enough to feed a bunch of hungry guys.  

The portions are good, the food is tasty and they have a lot of different dishes to satisfy any craving.

The scallion pancakes, although inexpensive and filling could use some more scallions in my opinion (they were a bit sparse and I wanted a little more scallion flavor with my dough).

I usually get kung pao beef because it's consistently tasty and satisfying although some of the rarer dishes that you don't see too often at other restaurants are surprisingly delicious as well (i don't recall exactly but there was a sour pork dish that was good).

I feel that the Chinatown location was a bit better than the Natoma location (probably because it wasn't as crowded and there was no wait).
author: Richard C.

description:
Wow, I actually found a place from my working in SF days that I never reviewed. I met a friend for lunch here once who loved Henry's so much that he once named it as one of his favorite five restaurants in the Bay Area. Henry's would have been lucky if I'd put it in my top 5,000.

It was okay, but not great. I went to the Sacramento location a couple times, too, but never understood the fuss.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Agree with fellow yelper Telisa K about the portion. It's huge. Food is good. Nothing amazing but  worked for us one night when we were really hungry in SF after our day of urban hike. Tried their green beans. We liked it!
We had trouble finding this place because it's hidden in an alley.The place is huge.
Service was fast and food ordered came out fast too! No BS here. Just the way I expect it to be. Love it!
author: Janet D.

description: Surprised they didn't have fried wontons at a Chinese restaurant, but had great pork fried rice.
author: Elise G.

description:
Service/friendliness is great! But the food isn't the BEST I've had. Don't all chinese restaurants have the spicy yellow mustard that you mix with shoyu? I was extremely disappointed when they told me they didn't have any and thought substituting my request with spicy chili peppers was good enough.

The lunch specials are decently priced and you get a good amount of food. My favorite thing that I've had here is probably the dumplings though! If only they were slightly cheaper? You don't get a whole lot for $4+.
author: Brad Y.

description:
The coworkers don't like this place, nor do many reviewers, but I have my go-to dish: Hot and Spicy Rock Cod fillet.

The fish the few times I've been here has been fresh, perfectly cooked and the right amount of spice. I can imagine the other dishes being too salty, but the fish is in large enough chunks to make it just right.

It's still way better than Fang nearby, better too much flavor than none!
author: Ryan V.

description: I give it 4 star and have been going there for a very long time. Disappointed that they will be closed on Saturdays from July onwards. I will have to go the one on Sansome.  Favorite is hot and sour chicken and onion cake.
author: Anil K.

description:
If the food wasn't so great, I'd still come to see Eddie, the world's best waiter. 
Come for the Cold Chicken Noodles. Stay for a visit with Eddie.

Favorites:
Cold Chicken Noodles
Diana's Meat Pie
Marty's Special
Onion Cakes
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Very tasty. One of my go-to places for a business meeting near Union Square. The prices are good.
author: Craig A.

description: Loooooove it! Diana's Meat Pie, who would have thought parmesan cheese in a Chinese dish but it works. Hot and Sour Beef, the sour was there but it wasn't overwhelming it was very balanced, again delicious. I never found anything greasy or overtly salty about any of the dishes that I have ordered. The portions are generous. My co-worker friend and I always order the Meat Pie to start, the Hot and Sour Beef and usually some other dish to try and rice. Prices are very fair, portions just right, a very satisfying experience. Recommended.
author: .James A.

description:
For spicy Americanized Chinese food and a table for 8, Henry's is your place.  Ain't nothing wrong with that.  Get there before 11:45 or you'll need to take your order to-go.

I don't know why everyone gets all wound up about a place needing to be authentic.  If the food is good then it's good, dammit.  Taco Bell never claimed to be authentic Mexican food, but if you want to get full for $3 and have your food within 3 minutes, then you're part of the Taco Bell target audience.  Authenticity has nothing to do with anything.

That said, Henry's is like Taco Bell.  Not like Demolition Man where every restaurant is Taco Bell, but in the sense that there are zero restaurants in mainland China where you can order something even remotely close to Diana's Meat Pie.  But who cares?  If you like it then get it and eat it and get on with your day.
author: Gary D.

description:
Henry's Hunan makes for a good lunch.   I've lost count of the number of times I've eaten lunch here with my coworkers, but it's a lot.

It usually takes quite a while to get seated, especially if you come with a large group of people.  Once you're here though, you'll most likely have a pleasant lunch with generous portions for a very reasonable price.   I recall that their chicken curry, their chicken chow mein, and their beef chow mein selections were all quite tasty.

Wouldn't drive out of my way to come here, but for a good lunch value, this is a safe bet.
author: David O.

description: In town for a conference. Gave this a place a try since near my hotel and I personally like spicy food for which this place is known for. Bottom line the food was salty, greasy, and honestly not all that spicy. Hot & Sour soup was solid but Henry's special and dumplings not up to par.
author: Jason S.

description:
bean curd and marinated pork was ok
beef and picked pepper was ok
author: Diane W.

description:
The first day my company moved into the neighborhood, my coworkers and I decided to eat at Henry's Hunan.  The ordering process was quick,. but the food took awhile to come out.  Everything we ordered was flavorful,. even the green onion pancake, came out very tasty. 

I also love the hot and sour soup,. a must have,. esp when youre feeling a bit out of the weather and need something warm to keep you going for the day.  

They can charge you for half a cup or a full cup,.. i barely finished a half cup and it was less than $5! 

Def a steal!

Will be back!
author: Chanel L.

description: My Chinese friends make fun of me for liking this place so much but I don't care. For gringos like me, the food is great! I really enjoy their Kung pao pork, Marty's special, fried fish, and soup. It's consistent and cheap. And the service is friendly, fast, and efficient. Great place to get lunch with coworkers.
author: David S.

description:
Yay for Henry Hunan!

Ok, so this place perhaps only deserves 3 stars based on food, but I look at the whole package. Service was friendly, I guess I beat the lunch rush as I was seated in a few minutes, and service was just really good! (i suffer from crappy services most places and have really learned how to appreicate a good server)

The food was good when you comapre it to the usual chinese places around here.  

We had the shrimp (no i don't remember which one) and the kung pao chicken.  We did the normal dishes not the lunch style ones, so the portion were good enough to get two people through lunch and dinner.

I'm going back tonight, so I'll do an immediate update with more food details.
author: Kym P.

description: Since I work near here I've been here 2 or 3 times. I have to say my first time there I wasn't too impressed. The food was ok as well as the service but once you realize what you're getting and that you're not paying through the nose for it, especially in the over-priced Financial District, then it becomes a reasonable place to eat basic Chinese food. I'm sure the purists won't like it but expectations are part of the experience, right? If you want something on the extreme other end of the scale then go to Hakkasan.
author: Rich M.

description:
Neither here nor there. My friend and I shared a Curry Chicken and Kung Pao Beef. I thought the flavors were there but the food was not as spicy as I expected (or wanted) it to be. I just compensated by adding some extra chili sauce. 

But the food comes out pretty fast and piping hot, and I really like that.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: This is my favorite Chinese place so far in the city. I love the spicy food. The service is simple. What else do you want
author: Donald M.

description:
I've now been there 8 or 9 times, and I've got to say: the place has grown on me. No, not in the "honey, what's that on your neck?" kind of way. 

This is in the good way.

The food is consistently good, they will heavily spice it up on request (and believe you me: I do request them to do it), and there's a good enough variety on the menu that I've never had to have the same combo of stuff twice. Service is pretty quick (even during the busy lunch). I leave with hunger satiated and wallet not totally emptied.

Do I have any particular favorites? I prefer only the dishes that have meat, rice, bean curd, tofu, or vegetables. Or some combination of those.

Yeah, I'm that picky. bwahaha
author: Tim B.

description: Just went there for lunch pick up to go - some of the best Kung Pao Chicken I have ever had.  Very flavorful sauce made from scratch.  Very authentic Hunan!
author: Phillip K.

description:
There just isn't enough time in my lunch hour to give 'Henry's Hunan.' Literally, this place is just too dang slow, and the food is not worth the wait. To make matters worse, service is an utter disaster. There's been no indication of who our server would be on both occasions I've dined here. Flagging someone down will yield a meek "okay" before they meander off to do something else. When service does arrive is brute and cold. 

I'd rather not waste my time and money on a business that does not match 4-star food with at least 2-star service!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I would have given a negative review if I could, but unfortunately, have to give 1 Star

This place is in the heart of the Embarcadero, and one of the places which gets  crowded on the weekday during lunch time. The service staff has no respect for the customers, complaints are not entertained, and staff is extremely disrespectful and inattentive.  The decor is cheap, service is pathetic, and food.. I shudder to think. 

Me and my friends walked in and nobody came to take our order for over 30 minutes, inspite of us trying to attract the waitresses there. I walked out of my seat, approached a waitress, and asked her to please take our order, as it was getting late for work. She said, yes , in a very wierd manner. Post that, nobody showed up for another 15 minutes. We finally decided to walk out . It was an extremely poor experience,  and on complaining to the lady at the door, she did not seem to care, and promptly asked someone else to fill the seats. 

I am surely not going back there, have completely lost respect for Hunan !!
author: Amit D.

description:
Curiously delicious. Smoked ham in Chinese food? Who knew?

The beef pie is everything they say it is. One is enough for two people.

Some delicious vegetarian options on the menu, but the kitchen has been known to prepare vegetarian dishes to order as well.

...and if somehow you need further motivation to dine at Henry's Hunan: the owners & staff are personable, very approachable folks.
author: Wesh W.

description: Sweet Chinese food here! Everything is always fresh and comes out pretty quick. The service is great and the menu has a pretty good selection. Everything I had ordered was super good and me and my friends had a ton to eat. Was a great time at a great place.
author: David T.

description:
WORST Hunan food..EVER!!! The waitress was really sweet - the atmosphere was okay...the food was inedible! 

When asked if the food was alright we said no - the waitress got the manager to come over and he asked what was wrong. We had ordered 3 dishes (shirmp and green beans, bbq pork with napa, and a vegetable dish) They were so salty that we absolutely could not eat them - and they all were plunged into the same brown sauce. when we explained to the manager that they were too salty - he told us we should have specified not to be salty and that we had obviously not eaten Hunan before....OMG, are you kidding me??? The food wasn't even spicy...we would have been happy to have our tongues scorched with chilies - NOT SALT!!!  

To finish it off the manager said it was the waitress because it was her first day...omg - why throw her under the bus for bad food???? She was a delight - poor thing working for such a bad place....
author: Ron W.

description:
I wonder if I ordered the wrong thing....

I've continued my quest to find new lunch options... 30 minutes for lunch definately keeps things interesting, but these days I'm cool getting lunch and just eating it at the desk.  I walked by this place a couple times, but it looked so small and dirty I was hesitant to try.

Walking in I was pleasantly surprised.  Nice decor, bustling for lunch with a line out the door... maybe I found my chinese fix nearby!

Sadly, the food was lacking.  They had a reasonably priced lunch special (broccoli beef for 6.75), but I figured I'd get my go-to mongolian beef and see how they did.  

Ugh.. first of all 11.75 total for my lunch is absolute BS when I"m eating togo chinese food.  Maybe the guy charged me for a dinner, but that was just rediculous.  

And the food?  It tasted so-so.  Portion was reasonably sized, but the amount of grease was a bit much.  And this is from a guy who LOVES dirty chinese food.. so that says something.  I actually got a stomach ache and didn't finish this bad boy up.

I guess I"ll give them another shot, but next time I'm definately getting the lunch special.   If they hadn't charged me $12 for a shitty lunch I'd have gone with 3 stars.
author: Joseph F.

description: all good. i love spicy fish here. i also like veg. fried rice, onion cake and soup.
author: Satyam S.

description:
Not sure if I can be objective on this one, but perhaps that is never the case. We have memories, evocations, associations and just plain old gut-feelings that all add to our experience of a place. 
 
This is a place I only go with my Dad and step-mom. They live in the neighborhood and know the manager. In fact Dad usually helps trim green beans while he waits for his to-go food. The manager always says an extra nice hello to me and always waits on us himself. So, it makes me feel special -so of course I am more inclined to be kind. Good memories, happy times.   
 
But sometimes I just needs me a Diana's meat pie. There must be a story to this menu item, and I don't know it, but last Thursday had been a rough day and knowing there was a piece of Diana's meat pie in my future made it all just seem a little better. When we walked in ( it was one of those super cold days)the heat was blasting (good!) and we walked by a table of three of SF's finest, EACH with a meat pie in front of them. I knew I was onto something - however we usually share one and that is more than adequate. So, how to describe it: I guess it's a Chinese pancake of some sort , though it seems like a tortilla to me, and with ground beef, lettuce and some kind of spicy sauce, it's kind of like a layered Chinese-American taco. I can only explains it's appeal as nostalgia but I like it mighty fine...but just a wedge in enough. 
 
The gang shared a hot and sour soup that all claimed was delicious. I had some of the of fat potstickers, plump little dumplings of pleasure. We then shared the smoked ham and veggies - salty, smokey and sublime -and the curry chicken which seemed a bit average to me, too many onions, but still overall good and warming on that particularly frigid day. Favorite dishes from other visits include the black bean rock cod (Dad's fav) and the smoked ham with green beans. 
 
Decor is cool, exposed brick walls, open and they have the heat on ( some places don't - believe me) but sometimes hard to converse at the larger circular tables.
author: Marie K.

description: I was so happy that the Hot and Sour soup was actually (spicy) hot and sour.  The shredded pork with celery was delicious, too.  I ordered take out, and when I got back to my hotel everything was still steaming hot.  Bring something to blow your nose because when they say spicy they mean spicy!
author: Kevin T.

description: Having been back here a few times, I think they deserve five stars instead of four.  Consistently good, food is very flavorful and well cooked.
author: Peter A.

description:
This place is pretty good for lunch in the FiDi. There is a decent mix of Chinese food and Chinese-American food.  I prefer the former.

Tops on my list:  the beef noodle soup and spicy won tons.  Don't expect lean pieces of meat.  We Chinese people love the fatty meat!!!  This soup is very yummy!
author: Eddie L.

description:
I was expecting hotter and spicier food, since Hunan cuisine is known for its use of chili peppers and hot sauces.  However, I was a bit put off by the fact that there was no straight Hunan Beef on the menu.

The restaurant is huge, lengthwise.  It's a bit confusing if you want to order take-out; you have to walk up to the cashier's window and place your order there, and then go back to the cashier's window to pick up your food order once it's ready.  Those who are visiting for the first time may not know who to approach, since the waitstaff that crosses your path doesn't offer any help or guidance.

The portions served are fairly large, and the food is tasty even though it's not as spicy as you may prefer.  A pretty good deal for the amount of money that you spend there.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Hidden in the alley...I was taken here a couple of year ago...it is now one of my fav spots for CHINESE food. Typical Chinese restaurant...ok with service, decor is blah, but the food is awesome! 

1) Meat Pie ( YOU must order this...its is simply delicious and I crave for this meat pie all the time) 
2) polish hotlink ( i don't know any other Chinese rest that serves this...try it) 
3) MOPO Tofu ( yummy also) 
4) chicken and cabbage ( tasty and different) 

I usually eat here after I go to John Collins...great eats for cheap! 

LUV IT!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Henry's Hunan is what I considered a good example of Americanized Chinese restaurant. It truly is! They serve dishes that are authentically Americanized Chinese with a menu offering dishes like Kung Pao Chicken, hot & sour soup, noodles soups, rice plates, and stirred fried dishes of everything and anything you can think of - shrimps, vegetables, beef, pork, or chicken. Is unfortunate that this restaurant is within walking distance from my business and I had to visit it occasionally for office social functions. Of the few times that I've visited (shamefully and feeling guilty for betraying my grandmother's cooking), I've forced myself to put down food that I wouldn't ever ordered nor want to be seen entering the restaurant. I would indulge my fellow Yelpers who are looking for my feedback on the dishes from Henry's Hunan:

- Meat Pancakes - 2 layers of deep fried flour pancake sandwiched with sautéed ground pork and shredded iceberg lettuce. It was neither tasty nor exciting. 1 order yield 5 huge servings. If you are small eaters, request that they cut it into 6 slices and that should still be plenty for everyone. You don't need that much of boring food. 

- Moo Shoo pork with pancake - Ahh...the overseas Chinese will agreed that this dish is a popular dish in an Americanized Chinese restaurant and is a favorite on the menu. Thin slices of pancakes and hoisin sauce are included for you to scoop in sautéed pork, shredded cabbage and mushrooms to make your own spring roll. 

- Hot & Sour soup - This is the only decent dish in my opinion. The soup is nice and hot (both temperature & spice) with lots of bamboo shoots, woodear fungus, tofu and have just enough sourness to wake up the taste bud. ($1 a bowl on the specials board for dine in only)

- Green Beans and Beef sautéed in black bean sauce - Green beans are always overcooked and came out mushy even though the beef slices are cooked perfectly. They just can't seem to get the beans out of the wok fast enough.

- Kung Pao Chicken - nothing to brag about here except that if you can't take spicy food, ask for mild as supposed to spicy. I can't distinguish the chicken pieces from the other ingredients in this dish because everything is cut into same size and covered with the red flaming sauce. 

- Sautéed eggplants with black bean sauce - the eggplants are literally covered with a layer of oil over it and the sauce under. It was greasy, bland and the eggplants so overcooked that it was literally 

- Tan-Tan Noodle - egg noodles topped with sautéed ground pork and spring onions. The noodles are soggy and the meat mixtures is blend and too greasy. 

- Rice plates - Available with all kinds of sautéed toppings. The dishes are generous serving (as if we are eating for tomorrow) with the rice piled high.

The taste of the food - after 2 dishes, everything tasted the same because everything is cooked or stir fried in the same bean sauce or spicy sauce and coded with a thick layer corn starch to thicken the sauces. Every dish is very heavy with the oil as if the chef worries that he isn't using enough oil to cook the food. I will say one admirable trait about Henry's Hunan is that they don't use MSG in their dishes unlike typical Americanized Chinese restaurant. 

If you are looking to try authentic Chinese cuisine such as Cantonese style, Sze Chuan or Hong Kong style, you will not find it at this place. This will never be on my top 10 list of Chinese restaurants in the city to go for a meal. I know my faith for more Americanized Chinese food at Henry's Hunan is sealed so long I am working around SOMA, I know I will be visiting Henry's Hunan again for more office gatherings.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
Definately the dumb kid of the Henry family restaurants. 
The food here is just prepared quickly and without flavor. At the Sacramento store the same dishes come alive with flavor in your mouth and make you come back for more again and again and again. 

I've been here 3 times, and there hasn't been a glimmer of hope for the food here. The service is nice but I go to restaurants to eat, not to be treated politely (though it does help). 

In contrast to their Sacramento street location the one here doesn't serve all the lunch specials all the time. Not a wise choice. 

There are just better places to to eat in the FiDi for people to waste time with this one. Go to the Sacramento Henry's for a treat, and don't forget to ask for the food spicy.
author: Alex M.

description:
After a really long day, all my fiance and I wanted was to order Chinese food. After looking at reviews and making our decision, we called Henry's happy and excited with anticipation...

Then they told us that because it was sprinkling outside that they could not deliver to us. When my fiance got on the phone and asked if this was the only reason why they weren't delivering, they told him that it was dinner time and they were too busy.

I usually hate yelpers who just complain about service, but I think that this is a poor reflection on this business' operating services. Who turns away customers because it is raining? Unfortunately for Henry's, I will not be returning...
author: Denise B.

description:
The "Diana's Special Meat Pie" is like the Cosco Busan oil spill in the stomach...so steer clear!!!

It made my "iron" stomach churn literally within 15 minutes after consumption...ugh...
author: Sue L.

description:
San Francisco has been surprisingly disappointing for me in terms of Chinese food, and Henry's Hunan is one of the worst offenders. I've come here with large mixed groups, and noticed drastically different responses to the food from Asian and non-Asian diners. So be prepared for a pretty gross experience if you fall into the former category. 

My sneaking suspicion is that the proprietors of this place don't really know Hunan cuisine, but chose it because a liberal use of chili peppers and hot sauce can conceal a lot of culinary shortcomings. Almost every dish is smothered in the same sauce. The best option here is the meat pie, which is, hello, not Chinese food? Every time I've been here was for lunch, by which time the tea was already basically the color and flavor of water. Wait... it's noon and the tea is worse than weak... but how many people eat at Henry's before 12 PM? So that means the tea leaves are probably left over from another day! And let's not speak of the fried rice...
author: Angela X.

description: My favorite restaurant. Amazingly good. Try the hot n sour chicken.
author: Paul H.

description:
Portions are really big and it's an affordable place. My husband and I usually get one entree, rice, and a soup and still take home food. The restaurant has two entry points so, it can be confusing sometimes when we try to get a table. 

It's not the most amazing or unique Chinese food, but it is satisfying when you want a quick fix.
author: T K.

description:
Another yelper and I came here for lunch so that we can update each other with our crazy lives.
We were seated right away and this was around 1pm. The food came fast and it was pretty cheap. 
I had the Chickin Chowmein and it was very tasty. The dumplings were really good too.
 I would come here again if I had the time..dammit now I want to go eat there right now.....
author: Lana K.

description:
Went here for dinner.  Had the number six, which seemed to be the Hunanese version of Joe's Special - stir fried spinach leaves with stems, scrambled eggs, chicken, and black string fungus.  Very tasty with white rice.  Can't say enough about their fried bread, which is a Hunanese version of naan bread, but is deep fried and not as dense.  

Good service, decent functional surroundings.  South of Market.
author: Doctor G.

description:
Fellow Yelper, Lana K., took me here to envelope ourselves in MSG and the newest gossip.

It was definitely delicious, and I would no doubt go back.  When you go, get the dumplings to start; part crispy, part steamed, all scrumptious.

We had the chicken chow mein, and diced chicken over rice.  It all came out to a little under $22.  Great value, if you ask me.
author: Vince S.

description:
My dad used to work nearby and growing up we'd have dinner here every once in awhile. Very fond memories of delicious food...

We went there one last time before his office moved, for old time's sake, and it was one of the worst experiences I've had at a restaurant. 

Service was terrible. Though our server was nice, they sat us far away from the rest of the tables where the other patrons were sitting. Maybe because there were two small children in our party and they assumed they would be disruptive.. It didn't bother me until it appeared the servers forgot we were there in the back corner. 

Food took too long, especially since we'd been seated about 15 minutes before they came back to take our order, and though we asked for mild dishes (again, small children) they were incredibly spicy. I mean, way over the top considering what we asked for. We couldn't help but think they did it on purpose. The portions were also smaller than I remembered. We ordered the same number of dishes we would at any Chinese restaurant and it barely fed 4 adults + 2 children. 

Very disappointed.

Okay, I'm done ranting.
author: Chris G.

description: I came here for my friends's co worker retirement party.   Had Chow mein, veggtables forgot the rest.  It was ok.   We ate in a room for large groups.  I think there is a dinning room.
author: John F.

description:
I said it once, I'll say it again: I know nothing about "real" Chinese food. All I know is that It's cheap, fast, greasy, and comes with some shitty-ass service but service didn't leave me feeling like the P.O.S. Westerner that I am. It's well ventilated, feels clean, and it get's an extra point for the workers snapping the heaps of green beans on a table--I want that job!).

I'm not sure about the difference between Hunan and Chinese food but I do know Henry's does not have chow fun. But they do have other forms of chow--ahem, chow mein. I like their shrimp chow mein solely based on the corkscrew shrimp they use--it's like eating little piggy tails...but shrimp! I'm into that kind of thing. Everything our group ordered was ridiculously greasy but good.

Best bets:
* Nothing beats day-old Chinese leftovers (besides pizza and mac n' cheese). Most of the greasiness gets absorbed...somewhere...and tastes damn good cold.
* Try the orange chicken. As my dining PIC said, "It's like candy."
author: Kristine W.

description:
Keep in touch with your network.  

When I went to "job hunting school," the lecturer talked about working my network.  "Sure," I thought.  "I am a contractor.  I move around all the time.  What kind of network do I really have?"  

This week I found out.  Friends I had worked with in the past invited me to a lunch party.  I've been going to Henry's Hunan since my students introduced it to me back in 2000, but this invitation wasn't really about the food.  

I phoned in my RSVP and attended.  Of the 17 who showed up, about 8 still worked for the company, and the rest were in various states of vacationing on their severance pay, job hunting, or working at their new jobs.  It was heartening to find a ready-made support group for an hour, and to catch up on each others' lives.  

Then, late in the hour, three of them took an interest in the fact that I was on the market.  I gave each of them a business card immediately, and told them I was ready whenever they had their requisitions funded.  Just like the gold mining business, there might not be gold dust in every pan of sand, but you keep panning.  You never know when it will pan out.  

So, we 17 each ordered a dish, and passed all of them around.  We pigged out on just about everything on the menu, and there was plenty of food left over.  Lots of garlic, lots of red peppers, lots of corn starch.  The tab, including tip, was $15 per person.  

Remember, you do have a network, even if you can't imagine who it is right now.  

--------------
P.S. when I was wandering around the wrong side of Mission Street I used Yelp on my cell phone to find the restaurant.  Yay Yelp!
author: David D.

description:
We were craving Kung Pao Tofu last night and tried the take out service.  Not really the same kung pao we've had at other places.  The tofu is silken and not chewy.  Sauce was more soy then anything.  

But the rice and fortune cookies were as expected :)
author: Sheetal S.

description: Back in my old stomping grounds. I hope the hunan is as spicy as I remember.
author: Marcie P.

description:
Henry's Hunan is our go to restaurant for large groups for birthdays or getting hired/ fired lunches. Its just a few blocks away from my office, much closer than making the journey to Chinatown. 

The staples here:
*Sweet and Sour soup (I love it!)
*Orange chicken
*Green beans
*Chow mein w/ a meat
*Meat pie
*egg rolls
*beef and broccoli 

The lines here can be kind of crazy - they only take reservations for 12pm and 1pm. No 1230 ressies for you! The service here is pretty cool and the food is consistent. But probably not anything to write home about to your Chinese mom or something.
author: Julie F.

description:
It ain't fancy.  It ain't luxury.  It's just good food.

Wimpy sensitive S.F. types can't stand this kind of place because it isn't:

1) the goopy sugary same-sauce House of Nanking shit
2) bland and vegetarian enough (go to Cafe Gratitude, hippie)
3) fancy fusion tourist crap like the dishes at Tommy Toy's. (Go fuck yourself Chad.  You too Brad, Brian, Steve, and _____insert generic Marina name here___! Eat and go make asses out of yourselves at the North Beach bars, trying to attract the Heathers and Kaitlyns of the world! :P

Fuck them and their negative reviews.  Try this place for yourself and form your own opinion.

Their hot sauce is the type I like. =)

The overly-PC sensitive vegetarian pussified hipster wimps in SF seem to obsess about Sriracha, which is great in pho, but the peppers-in-hot-oil stuff they use and sell at Henry's is the good stuff that I and REAL world travelers like.

It's the stuff that REAL Chinese people (you whitewashed eyelid-surgery Twinkie girls don't count) like to use for won ton soup on both sides of water.  If you can't find this kind of sauce in Chinatown or on Clement street, you can certainly buy it at Henry's.  Try it, with a few sprinkles of white pepper, on won ton noodle soup.  Nice, huh?

My favorite items at Henry's Hunan:

1) the harvest pork
2) the kung pao shrimp
3) henry's special (similar to kung pao shrimp, but with more seafood, vegetables and that lovely black fungus that's popular in China, Hong Kong, and Belleville, the newer Parisian Chinatown).

order some steamed white rice, a pitcher of water (you'll need it) and chow down.

If you don't know how to use the small bowls and the chopstick-bowl-rice-food-to-mouth shovel method, just ask.

If you aren't willing to eat that way, ask for a fork and eat off the plates like the rest of the gringos.
author: Justin C.

description:
Meh it's not really Hunan food, more like Chinese food.  This place is located in an alleyway and you can literally walk through it to another street!  

I ordered take out here and it was a bit confusing.  There is no hostess taking the order, only a cash window.  So here I am standing in line with people who already ate and me ordering food.  The place is ok for the lunch time rush.  The price is fairly priced.  Nothing really special or unique about this place.... 3 STARs.
author: Elliot Y.

description:
This location is tucked away in a neat little alley.  Going here feels a little seedy, and I feel like I've found something secret!

Pretty decent as far as Chinese food goes, especially if you like things spicy.  Some favorites are the spicy shrimp with bean curd, braised fish balls with vegetables, and the homestyle plate of pickled vegetables (I forget the exact name of the dish).  You can get a lot of food for $10.

Quality and service have been consistent every time I come here.  I recommend going at night when the place is dead, since it can get really crowded at lunch.
author: Alison M.

description:
Good, classic Chinese food in SOMA.

My coworkers and I like to come here for lunch when we're craving Chinese.  This place is great for big groups (we usually have 10 people), but make a reservation ahead of time and come in at 11:30am or 1pm.  Service is quick and the food arrives lightning-fast.

A few of our favorites:

1) Meat Pie: think of it as a Chinese hamburger, very tasty.
2) Marty's Special: a flavorful stir-fry of smoked ham and veggies
3) Sweet n Sour Chicken: we always order double.
author: Vanessa K.

description: How did this place get only 3 stars? I practically lick my plate clean every time I go and order the most delicious curry chicken. I must say, though, Hunan food including Henry's is not for everyone. And not every item on the menu is fantastic but the ones that are good are awesome. I love this place. There is a reason why it is always packed.
author: Tom F.

description:
I would have never stepped into this place, reasons being 1) good Chinese in the FiDi? (gimme a break), 2) good spicy Chinese food in the FiDi? (come on, now you're teasing me...), and 3) my experience with restaurants that have "Hunan" in their name have never fared very well.

But as fate would have it, my department at work decided to hold our annual holiday luncheon here.  First off, lemme just say that this was a total downgrade from our usual holiday luncheons at Perbacco and Atrium.  But times are tough, and we have to save the firm a bit of dough, so I shouldn't be complaining.  At least we had the opportunity to get away from the office for a couple hours on the firm's dime, right?  Going anywhere on the firm's dime is A-OK with me.

But Henry's food was not A-OK with me.  Everything was either way too salty or was doused in the same cornstarch-y gravy.  The only two things that I would probably consider ordering if I ever came here again would be their dumplings (actual homemade dumpling skins!) and spicy shrimp with string beans.  They claim they don't use MSG in their food, but I came back to the office very parched and feeling slightly lethargic.  If you ask me, those sound like MSG-induced symptoms.

Henry's was able to save itself from a 1-star rating for the efficient service they provided our three very large and very rowdy banquet tables and their nice selection of draft beers.
author: Diane L.

description: Got the veggie chow mein and the dumplings. While the dumpling  flour was good, both dishes were completely drenched in oil. Yuck, I could barely eat any of it.. Points for faster service than I expected, and for actually accepting Amex (a rarity for Chinese places esp. in SF).
author: anjali s.

description: Never mind that it isn't real Chinese food - sometimes I get in the mood for spicy stuff.  What will keep me away from this place is the petty waiters that tack on 15% to your bill - *AFTER TAX* - for a table of 6 or more people.  The service that day was poor - took a long time for the person to take the order (had to wave our hands and shout) - and then a long time to get the bill.
author: Steve S.

description: This is my first Yelp review and I feel it is only natural/right to give it to Henry's Hunan. Sure, it may not be the best chinese in San Francisco, or the swankiest Asian decor, or the healthiest of meals; however, Henry's Hunan is the San Francisco version of Soul Food for me. I get the same thing at least once a week during my lunch break; Meat Pie, Dumplings, Hot & Sour Soup, and Kung Pao Chicken. The meat pie is crispy and delicious, the dumplings are soft, the soup is perfect for foggy days, and the kung pao will clear your sinuses if you eat too fast. Henry's, I salute you and hope you read this someday.
author: Claude M.

description:
Thinking I might be fighting a cold, hot and sour soup was my goal for lunch today. Henry's filled that order and my stomach, without a problem. Upon arrival, ice water and complimentary hot tea were immediately delivered, and my food came out quickly as well. The soup broth seemed to have thickener in it, but was otherwise quite tasty, with the right amount of zing. I was also impressed that a Small ($4.50) was a 7" bowl, equal in size to a large bowl of cereal. My pork dumplings (6 for $4.50) were also quite good, served in a strong, spicy soy sauce. The bill came quickly, and I had to remember that payment is all handled at a single counter, not at the table.

Lunch here was also fitting given the season. I'm not especially religious, but with no family in the area for Christmas, I intended to be a "good, traditional Jew" and go out for Chinese food and a movie tonight. Alas, dinner plans changed and the current movie selection is mediocre, but I still got my Chinese food for the day! Mazel Tov!
author: Bill B.

description: So much salt! I had the kung pao chicken...man, it was salty. Restaurant looks nice though! We also got a table relatively quickly on a Friday, for how many people were here during the lunch rush.
author: Alexander L.

description: I've never been able to finish a meal here. I think it's the oozing grease and excessive onions in almost every dish. And I've had a couple of varied dishes now.  It's not horrible, but it almost seems like a chore to eat their food.  The dishes just never seem balanced. There is always too little of something .or too much of something else.  It's always packed whenever I come, so be prepared to wait. The service although quick, is usually haphazard and rushed.  It's the kind of place that I may go to for a work lunch,  but it's definitely not a place I'd go out of my way to visit.
author: Jessica T.

description:
excess of salt + amplitude of oil + quick high heat cookin' = henry's hunan.....largescale fidi chinese restaurant.....large crowd no reservation dinner....henry's lax 'n' empty.....

note: no relations to henry's hunan....or immediate family
author: Hen A.

description: I've been dining at this wonderful restaurant ever since it was in its first location, a tiny hole in the wall. I don't get to San Francisco often anymore, but when I do, I make it a point to eat at Henry's.  And for 25 years, I've told all my San Fran-bound friends that if there is only one restaurant that they visit while there, make it  Henry's, that's it's the best Chinese food on the planet!
author: Donna W.

description:
Still one of the best in San Francisco.
I have not found a Curry Chicken like this anywhere. 
Diana's Meat Pie will not travel and must be eaten on the spot. I give it about a 10 min decay window. Smoked Ham is the star of the show, and Henrys special is Scallop,chicken and shrimp, Marty's is Smoked ham with chicken. When there was a Stock Exchange in San Francisco this was the official restaurant for 30 years! This review is for all their branches.
author: Paul L.

description:
Unfortunately, we often get henry's hunan when we have team lunches because it is so close to my office.   I don't understand why people love the food here.  It's awful!

For one thing, it's way too expensive for what you get.  If you get a shrimp dish, they split the shrimp in half lengthwise so you are actually getting less shrimp than you THINK you are getting.  Also, many of the dishes are packed full of "filler" material like carrots, onions, and cabbage.  The plate might feel like it weighs 3 lbs, but I guarantee more than half of it is the filler crap.  

If I have to eat food from here because we're getting it comped by work, I will reluctantly order the green beans with shrimp.  At least the green beans are usually fresh and tasty.   I won't be happy about it, though.   *shakes fist*
author: Courtney Y.

description:
Would you like some Chinese food with your salt?

What is the deal with this place?  I'm Thai I can deal with salt but this place is out of hand.  I never send anything back, but I ordered the Mongolian Beef and couldn't do it. It was so incredibly salty.  I told the waiter to try it, he came back with a sad face... enough said.
author: Nopadon W.

description:
Having...hard...time...breathing...heart...racing...too...much...msg...

MSG or not, I'm seriously feeling this way after a few bites of their garlic chicken. Everything was so starchy and salty. On our way out, I saw the staff making pot stickers at one of the tables and they looked good, but I think I'll have to pass.
author: Connie C.

description:
By my third visit, I have two favorite dishes:  The smoked ham with string beans, and the Henry's special (smoked ham and chicken).  

Vegetarians get a laugh from the menu which says, "Americans consume too much meat."   One of my co-workers tried a veggie Kung Pao made just for her (not on the menu), and it seemed to satisfy.  There are plenty of other veggie dishes to go around, just as tasty as the meat dishes.  

I agree that the theme (as well as the name of the restaurant) is way off tune, and if I'm not mistaken, the smoked meat is based on Taiwanese recipes, not Hunan.   But the tacky atmosphere sets us up for an enjoyable meal.   Nothing spectacular here, but it definitely passes as a dot com mess hall and a palate-pleaser!
author: Daniel C.

description:
I might be biased here...perhaps it's the headache or massive stomach ache I get each time I come here to eat...or maybe...just maybe...it's the fact that EVERYTHING contains the same thick spicy sauce and therefore TASTES THE SAME.  Yeah...that might be it, too.  My co-workers (one in particular) love this place; I've been here several times and I don't see what makes this place so special.  The food is decently priced, I'll give you that.  You have to get here by 11:30 if you want to get a seat though. 

Avoid the seats next to the guard rail, unless you don't mind staring at people's asses all throughout your meal.
author: Daniela L.

description:
1. It's been there forever. Longer than yelp! and longer than most yelpers. It must have something that some of you are missing, because no business lasts long downtown if it can't attact customers. 
2. Yes, salty and spicy, I wouldn't eat here every day. 
3. But I like salty and spicy and where else can you get Hunan Polish Sausage?
author: jim b.

description:
First of all, I'd like to start off by saying that I usually prefer things on the saltier side.  Yes, I've probably got a high sodium intake, like the rest of America . . .

With that said, I've been here a couple of times now . . . the first time I went with simple standards, Kung Pao chicken and Mongolian beef.  Both had decent flavor, but that flavor was almost completely overpowered by salt!  At first I thought it was just me, but then noticed that everyone had finished their water (NOT because of spiciness).  

Okay, I figure this was just a fluke, and go back again . . . got the sliced cured pork and beef & dumpling soup.  Now the sliced cured pork was pretty damn tasty (where the two stars come from), but also salty.  This saltiness is to be expected though since it's *cured/salted.  The beef in the dumpling soup was fairly tender, and dumplings were better than the frozen variety, but only marginally.  Again, the broth was so salty that I had to tank my water to keep my mouth from shriveling up.  

I might try this place one more time, but only because I'm a 1/2 block away, and they had an exceptionally cute hostess this last time!
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
First of all, I'm not from China, let alone Hunan, but thats moot because taste is the theme of my review not authenticity.

Just because its my heritage does not gives me superior tastebuds fo r trying indian food. Similarly its moot to bring up that its not real chinese food. Just eat the food if you like it. If you dont like it move on.

I dont fret over the fact that French Laundry's got an iffy indian dish set on their tasting menu, served with "pappadoms" go figure. Its moot to mention that papadums, will kill your tastebuds by sticking the gooey left over lentils on your tongue, and anything you try afterwards will be less then ideal. (you can wash it down with wine, or surreptitiously use your finger to scrape it off your teeth and gums). but I'm digressing. This when you consider the price of $240/person is little high. But you just shut up and eat the dish they make to see what creative rendition has the chef made for you, not withstanding your skepticism.

Same goes for Henry's hunan. sick'n'tired of people dogging on it. for not being authentic chinese or not from hunan. I'm sorry thought never crosses my mind ever or any of my friends and colleagues I know , that they are going to a specific Hunan cuisine restaurant. Its a chinese restaurant serving spicy/salty/greasy chinese food in the FD,CT and SOMA (my favorite being this one, FD).

I have been coming here since 2001 every other week or so. Food is damn good, fried rice, String bean chicken, kung pao chicken, and mongolian beef are the gold standard items here, orange chicken is ok too but not really my thing. Also thier vegetarian dish of cooked edamame with picked something.. is curiously tasty as well.

Thing is, be it may, that place was designed to cater to wider american populace but they do a damn good job at that. Long lines attest to that. Its ok I dont feel guilty that I'm not eating "real authentic hunan cuisine", if I crave authentic chinese folk's chinese food I would head out to Clement st. china town, or Irving st china town, 8 Immortal restaurant on Taraval. 
Heck, I would even drive downsouth to Ranch 99 plaza in Milpitas for good selection of chinese/taiwanese restaurants, or I would goto Cupertino Village in Cupertino of course, for some modern taiwanese/chinese fare with their interpretation of american classics.

But I'm digressing, point is, I have had plenty of experience with chinese cuisine in bay area, and Henry's Hunan holds its own, because it taste good to me and most people in my circle who have been introduced to it. 
And I can see that other peolpe (minus the some folks yelping about it) thinks the same. because place remains packed on monday, and fridays like, after the weekend people cant wait to get their hands on some "hunan cuisine" ha ha.

Not a fan of the soup here, Kung Pau and String bean occasionally can be less then perfect, it all depends on if the cooking chef who excels at it is taking a break. Meat pie dish is also great, here, little unusual but great.

Will I go back? let me digest the string bean chicken and mongolian beef from this afternoon, and I will get back to you.
author: An u.

description:
I like Henry's Hunan! Okay, so it isn't the best Chinese food around but it's close to the office and the service may not always be fast but it's always friendly- the staff is really nice! I've had a few dishes I haven't been crazy about but they have some really great ones too. My faves are the Garlic Chicken, Spicy Shrimp with Bean Curd and Braised Rock Cod. 

Also, how can you not like a place that features a dish called Diana's Meat Pie on the menu??!!!
author: Donna V.

description:
Indeed, Henry's Hunan is the 'best Chinese restaurant in the world.' as it's often called. While some insist upon quoting the original scripture here in support, others maintain to this day that it is the best - despite the fact that in 1976 "The New Yorker"  called it the 'best Chinese restaurant in the world!'
So...
Best known for being called the best Chinese restaurant in the world for the fourth consecutive decade, Henry's Hunan serves foods so delectable, so sublime as to render such prior discourse concerning its relative merits so crude in its reliance upon comparative terms that speak nothing to this experience. Such fantastically delicious is the spiciness that the hunan house bean curd (say 25 times hot) offers that to call it the best in San Francisco understates the point.

Religious allusions and allegories usually aid clarity. So, to flesh out this point with an allegory: when faced with religious epiphany, those so inclined are apt to speak of their god's glory, etc. - and not the relative merits of this god compared to the other gods, and thereby eschewing the "first commandment" in exodus wherein the ineffable god goes on record insisting upon being #1 and that everyone hold all the other gods as second fiddles at best.  Although widely criticized for this shrewd move (not least of all those looking to improve the fiddle section), it seems almost quaint now in its understatement and has over time garnered much praise (even among monotheists, to whom it clearly does not apply): Firstly, for its role in providing much-needed filler in what's become the top all-time top-ten list - The Ten Commandments, and secondly for its role in silencing dissent.

So, much like the religious experience trivializes religious texts, so too does such an experience at Henry's Hunan trivialize not only the claim to being the "world's best," but renders such commentary irrelevant.
So, goodbye New Yorker
and Hello Henry's Hunan!
author: ryan c.

description:
"????!"
That's Chinese for "Spicy and delicious!" I love the Hunan. Any food that comes to your table with red chilies sticking out of it has to be good. Their daily specials are really yummy (the Monday Kung Pao Chicken special is especially recommended). The string bean dish is also a hit. Order the onion cake...it's phenomenal.
Try to show up a little early for lunch, as the lines are long. The service is a bit on the slow side, but the food more than makes up for it.
author: KebabKing ..

description:
The service fluctuates from v v good to totally antsy. But the food is good. I have tried most of their seafood, and they're pretty darn good. 

try it...a true Chinatown classic.
author: Sav B.

description:
Gross.... why does this place exist? It's amazing how standards for Chinese food can be so low for people to actually eat here. Either the Chef must not taste his own food or he has no taste buds to figure out how bad the food is. Avoid the mongolian beef... if you can call it beef. It's nothing but grease and salt with mystery items called meat.
