My coworkers who are not very familiar with good Chinese food...likes going here. Then again they eat nothing but fast food. BUT honestly, I would rather go eat at a McDonald's  than this "restaurant."
author: Bert T.

description:
Interior definately looks unlike any Chinese restaurant I've ever seen. It's industrial and mauve.
Food good. Greasy and fried, but good.
And there's a framed article reviewing the restaurant from the New Yorker.... in 1976!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Take Out:  I ordered Shredded Pork and Celery and got Shredded Pork and Green Bell Peppers...

I hate Green Bell Peppers.
author: LittleBird 8.

description:
This place packs 'em in for lunch, and a line out the door should serve as dire warning that even once you're seated the service will be interminably slow.  But keep in mind that the land office business at Henry's has nothing to do with service or atmosphere, but everything to do with the food, which is terrific.  

I tend to steer towards the vegetable dishes at Henry's, and I see other comments on Yelp about the meat dishes being a tad greasy, which seems to validate that strategy.  Onion cakes are a favorite starter, and my particular favorite of the vegetable entrees is the eggplant, which is  delicious, and just spicy enough to remind you it's Hunan, but not enough to send steam out of your ears.  

The decor, if one can call it that, is dreary and institutional, with all the charm of a concrete bunker.  The payment system was clearly modeled on downtown parking garages, with the cashier securely behind a glass window, lest an unruly diner be tempted to take a pop at him for the crummy service they surely received.  But those irritants aside, Henry's is still a pretty good choice for an excellent lunch.
author: Hugh B.

description:
Awsome food but don't get caught up to see who can eat the hottest food!  That hot sauce sauce you add when say hi when it exits the next day!  

Awesome customer service and great food!  We always get Diana's Meatpie (even though I've never seen this dish anywhere else before),  the Marty special, chicken string beans.

Note that you need to pay at the front so don't think sit at the table too long waiting.  If credit card, only Visa.  And, lastly, this truely is a fave lunch hangout so get there early if you are dining in!  Like, 11:45AM!
author: Lily S.

description:
Everything tastes the same here.   I have drank a gallon of water in the 15 minutes since I left this place and I am still thirsty!  We got several dishes and none were all that great, and they all tasted pretty similar, so if you do go here, don't waste your time looking at the menu, just pick anything, it's all the same.  We had to wait forever for a waitress to talk to us, the food came out in random order, spaced 10 minutes apart...and the thing was, there was a line out the door when we left!  Who would wait in line for this place?

Much better places in the city to go to, don't waste your time here.
author: Pele N.

description:
Henry's Hunan isn't exactly fabulous chinese food, but for about a year, my friends and I frequented it *every* week for their Kung Pao Chicken special.. Around 10am, someone would send an email around the office with just the words... "Kung Pao?" in the subject.. and those who were in, would simply reply all.. "In".. or sometimes you'd get creative and say something like "Kung Pao Me."

So, on average about six of us would all go each week, and everyone would order the Kung Pao Chicken over rice, extra spicy.  If you didn't order the Kung Pao you felt like that dude that didn't order Kung Pao, and c'mon.. it's all about some healthy peer pressure.  Then we'd sit there and sweat through the super spicy tasty dish...  It wasn't always consistent for some reason, and that was part of the fun.. some weeks, we'd pass the guys that didn't go to kung pao and tell them "hey.. kung pao was good this week."

And.. like clockwork.. around 2:37pm after kung pao you feel completely and utterly lethargic.  sometimes in pain.  maybe it was the spicyness, or the grease, or the secret Kung Pao sauce, but I swear you could set your watch by it...  Suddently, all the delight that KPC gave you just a few hours before was all gone, replaced by some civil war being waged in your innards.

But.. for some reason, when the new week rolled around, all was forgotten, and someone would send the fated "Kung Pao?" email around the office, and the insipid cycle would start all over again... 

I only stopped going to Henry's after I quit my job and no longer worked in the neighborhood.. I was just down in the old hood this morning, and if I had only been there during lunchtime, I might have just stopped in... I miss the Kung Pao.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
Came here today for lunch with my co-workers. We each ordered a dish (6 dishes in total, plus dumplings), and MAN, every thing was really good! The sauces were very tasty (I recommend the Hunan Scallops), and the food was just good overall!

I'll def be coming back here for lunch! 

I can't comment on the price/food quality, though, b/c I didn't pay this time:)
author: Ian C.

description:
+1 star for their ability to accomodate groups at rush hour.

-1 million stars for their uncanny ability to turn my entire digetive tract into a ride-all-day-for-free waterslide.
author: joe b.

description:
I've eaten at Henry's for lunch three times in as many months, and the upshot is: the food is great, the service is consistently awful:

* The last time I went, the waiter seems to have forgotten that we existed; we waited for 35 minutes before asking where our food was. Only after asking did it come, and in that time, no one checked in on how we were doing, asked if we wanted more tea or water or offered an explanation.

To add insult to this injury, the table of 4 next to us was being constantly refilled with rice, water, tea, etc.

* The second to last time I took someone there, we ordered the EXACT same thing; after waiting the standard Henry's 30 minute wait, the waiter brought our food to us. He handed me my plate, and then told my dining companion that the kitchen had made his with shrimp, not chicken like he ordered, and then asked if that would be OK.

I was floored; it was like they needed a book to explain to them how restauranteuring works: "See, there's a big book, with food you are willing to prepare for people; when your customers ask for that particular item of food, it turns out: that's probably the food they want! Asking your customers if they'll just take any ol' random crap you bring to them is... bad form."

* Another time, I wasn't finished with my meal, and the table buser came along, and threw all of my food away. I was going to get a to-go box, but I appreciate that apparently he thought I was too fat for one.

I can't, in good conscience, take colleagues and prospective customers to Henry's anymore, which is a real shame, because the food is pretty good.

But we can't usually afford to take a 90 minute lunch, and I've had a hard time explaining to people whom I've hyped up "this great hunan place" why the table next to us is getting exquisite service while we're sitting there, being neglected.

If you do have 90 minutes to spend on your lunchtime, and you don't really care if they listen to your order or not, then it's a great place.
author: Paul R.

description: Great lunch spot. Really good Kung Pao, etc.
author: Jim B.

description: One of my all-time favorite restaurants anywhere. Just give me a beansprout salad and an order of fishballs and I'm in my happy place.
author: Paprika P.

description:
I haven't had Chinese like this in a while, and when I was there I was not disappointed.  The dishes were fairly large for the small price and the service was friendly.  I went with a group of 6, and we each ordered one dish to share with everyone, and I can't say a single one was subpar.  Highly recommend.

Don't let the alley that it's in deter you from tasting the delicious food.
author: Nancy C.

description:
This place is insanely amazing.  My favorite downtown lunch spot for the past 10 years.  A necessity at least once or twice a month.  For in house dining, get there before 12 or prepare to wait.  For take out, call it in, they have daily rice plate specials. 

Salty...Yes.  Greasy...Yes.  Hot & Spicy...Yes, even hotter if you request it.   Tasty...Hell Yes!

This is place is a haven for white people craving the tasty spicy hot goodness.  According to people on other reviews, this is not "real Chinese food".  If that is true, then I don't want "real Chinese food".  I want my Henry's Hunan.  I've also been here with people from China, non-Hunan province, and they also have enjoyed it.

This place makes my bald spot sweat and my fat belly swollen...and I love it.  A true feast with friends every time I go.  We believe there is a Dragon in the kitchen emptying his special sauce onto every plate.  That is why it tastes so good!

I recommend the following:
Eliza's Meat Pie - An appetizer must (Think Taco Bell's Mexican Pizza they used to have back in the day, but better tostada, no beans,  and better)
Bean Curd & Meat Sauce
Kung Pao Pork - Hella Spicy
Curry Chicken 
Beef & String Beans
Hot & Sour Beef

For those that are truly insane, get the Henry's Bacon.  Basically, part of the stomach of a pig in a bowl of broth.  This is not like any bacon we were used to.  Prepare for the staff to stand around and watch you eat it and keep asking if you like it.  Nod, smile, and force it all down.

Sack up and eat what the Dragon has cooked up for you.
author: Nate B.

description: I might be biased because I ate here on a cold rainy day after an afternoon of drinking like a sailor. But something about Hunan cuisine just hits the spot for me. We ordered a bunch of things, and they all came out flavorful and spicy! The meat filled pancake is a must! The service was speedy, nothing fancy. All reasonably priced.
author: Mish N.

description:
Although I hear from all my Chinese friends that the food here is not "true" Hunan style, for the price I still feel that it's one of the best places to eat Chinese in the downtown San Francisco area. And as my family says, "It is what it is." So get on line and enjoy their delicious food for what it is - Hunan or not.

And let me preface this review by saying that I grew up on "Chow Mein" from Staten Island, New York in the 70's and 80's. And that I personally was very surprised to find that "Chow Mein" on the West Coast was a fresh noodle dish (no, I'm not kidding). Our "Chow Mein," as it was called, was more like a soupy mix of onions, celery, sprouts, and pork strips which you would clump on top of a plate of rice and then sprinkle dry, short, Chinese noodles on top of. Like Chinese croutons of a sort. Anyway, I've come a long in the past 16 years and have become very picky about my Chinese food no matter what style it claims to be (Although I secretly am still curious about those dry, flat, crouton-like noodles and where I can get some).

Anyway, as with any new restaurant I was a bit skeptical the first time I entered Henry's Hunan at 110 Natoma Street in downtown San Francisco. While waiting on the long line to get in, I read most of the plaques and awards on the wall but I stopped on one and squinted my eyes a bit. Then it registered, "Oh my gawd! That's Don Johnson!" WTF?!? Then the line moved quickly and we sat down at a large round table. The waiters are quick and there in minute or two and soon we were eating Spring Rolls and Dumplings. Minutes later, our food orders arrived and before we knew it we were nearly licking our plates trying to get just one more taste before we had to go back to work. It was a pleasant dining experience over all.

All that said, I've been eating at Henry's on and off for the past few years and here's the skinny on the place. First of all if you want to avoid the lunch lines you should go either before 12 noon or after 1PM. Parties of two usually get pulled quickly from the line and sat first, but large parties of five or more usually don't wait that much longer as the line moves pretty fast due to their large lunch room (notice I didn't call it a dining room; that's because it has more of a lunch room feel than an actual dining room).  

Once seated you'll probably wonder what you should order. For two people, I recommend splitting two appetizers and one entree as the dishes tend to be pretty hearty. That generally that will run you around $25 with tax and tip included. As for which appetizers definitely try the Hot and Sour Soup. It's pretty hearty and has great spicy undertones and a "small order for two" will get you both about two bowls each. The Spring Rolls are also a favorite of mine as they are made fresh and delicious. One order is three spring rolls cut in half (six halves). The Dumplings (6 served) are served more like pot-stickers, come in a mid sized bowl, and are also pretty darn good. I usually don't order the Onion Cake because I love the other three appetizers so much, but it is a favorite of many of my friends and so I get treated to it now and again. 

For entrees I've had several Tofu dishes, Black Bean Chicken, and several variants of the Chow Mein noodle dishes (yes, I mean the good kind). But my two favorite dishes are the "String Beans and Shrimp" and the "Shrimp & Chicken Chow Mein". The String Beans and Shrimp has a spicy garlic and black bean sauce, isn't stingy on shrimp, and can pack quite a kick so I generally ask for it served mild so my mouth doesn't burst into flames or even worse; the lower part of my digestive track. However, the Chow Mein also has a little kick, but never anything to be worried about. And because I love Chicken and Shrimp above all things else in this great world, I just cut right to the chase whenever I order it. I have tried a number of other dishes and I think they are all pretty good. But in general I try to avoid the fried dishes like Orange Chicken or "Sweet and Sour [insert meat type here]" because they tend to be very heavy on the breading. But if you want a real professional view, check out Greasepig who has been visiting Henry's Hunan for years and has given almost every dish in the place a 10 point scale review http://greasepig.com/henrys/

There is one thing you should be aware of when you're in a group of three or more people. My friends and I believe that there is an ancient Chinese curse placed on one random person whenever you have more than two at your table. For some reason, almost every time a group of us goes, one lucky person always winds up waiting 10 or more minutes longer for their dish. To be honest, it may actually only be 5 minutes, but when you're hungry, and all your friends are stuffing their faces, and then you realize you're "that person", it feels like a heck of a long time. Fortunately the food is so good, you'll forget about the curse until the next time it happens...
author: George L.

description: The key word here isn't "Henry" but rather "Hunan".  Everything that's good about this place is simply the fact that it's *not* Mandarin or Cantonese-style Chinese food.  I salute Henry's for that simple fact.  Still, Henry deserves a knock or two for the sheer and utterly avoidable grease factor, but the ultimate proof point is that I've been coming here for 20-odd years...
author: Laurence W.

description:
Usually come here with a big group for some cheap and spicy Chinese food. Most all of their dishes are spicy and at some point you will find that they all look and taste the same. I love spicy food.

Also love the shredded pork wraps, a non-spicy dish.

Service is always slow, from waiting (if you show up after noon there will definitely be a line), to getting the server to your table if you do not sit right next to the kitchen. Plan a long lunch.
author: T L.

description:
Rule of thumb: Don't eat in a Chinese restaurant if none of the customers are Chinese.  I generally follow this rule, but I make an exception with Henry's.  For me, it's just nice to eat non-Cantonese once in a while.  Favorite dishes here are kung pao chicken, string beans without meat (great wok HAY!), and the smoked ham with string beans.

I've eaten at all four Henry's Hunan restaurants because I've worked within a ten minute stroll of all of them: the one on Sacramento when I worked in the FiDi; the one on Bryant when I worked at 8th and Townsend; and the one on Sansome when I worked at the Ice House.  The Natoma Street location is now the closest one to my office.  Maybe it's the recency effect, but I feel this one is the best of the four.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
Henry's was where we would go on days at the office when we needed something a little special. Their lunch specials always rocked and were a great value. I miss the days of Henry's.

Beware, if you go for dinner, it is usually a ghost town. The food is still great and the service is still good but it feels weird eating in such an empty restaurant when you are used to the lunchtime hustle and bustle.
author: Neely M.

description:
Why I like this place because it is/has
- reasonably priced and huge portion
- good selections of food
- tons of SPICY food
- great for a big group
- great place to dine after 111 Minna :D
- super fast service
- pretty clean

My coworker shared this amazing page with me, it has review of every dish on the menu. http://greasepig.com/henrys/ SO I don't have to say more about each dish. :)
author: Ervinna L.

description:
We have a little plan and we are going out once a week with our teacher to lunch.  She is an SF native and is showing us all the best places.  So this week's lunch was off to Henry Hunan.  Oh heaven.

Best Chinese food I have ever had.  We had sweet and sour chicken, broccoli and beef, Kung Pao shrimp, Henry's special and garlic chicken.  All were so good.  We had three rounds of dumplings, the best chow mein I have ever had and some delicious fried rice.  This place was so good I wouldn't mind eating there once a week!
author: Bree W.

description: When I am in SF at lunch time, I stroll over here for Hunan Chicken over rice -- with the garlic sauce added.  Instead of whole peppers, they add hunan sauce to the chicken & veggies in the wok.  Not a meal to precede a business conference, as it stays with you for several hours.  But if you want something hot, spicy, and filling, this is one way to go.
author: Jerome F.

description:
I'm not a big fan of chinese food, but I went to this place with the friends.
I actually enjoyed the food. It was fresh, well cooked and flavorful.
They have family style serving and we had fun sharing the food talking.

I have to take off one star for one problem. Four of us had to wait for some time before we got seated. There was 6 people table available. When we requested this table, the host told us that he has to hold it for bigger group. That was not nice.
author: Sergey Z.

description:
My first Hunan experience many months ago was a forgettable, and painful one.  

We had stumbled upon another place in the FiDi after an afternoon of drinking, ordered the works, and combining our hunger and numbed senses we stuffed the food down our esophaguses the second it arrived.  

Not so smart when you're dealing with food so spicy that has the capability of fueling a small car based on the fire it lit inside me.

Being prepared for the worst then I went here today with the mindset that I'd take things slowly, and have plenty of tea/water and white rice on hand to put out any small flames that I'd encounter either within my mouth or intestines.

Luckily Henry knows his audience--a bunch of non-Chinese pansies who don't have flame retardant tongues and stomachs--and put in just the right amount of spices to the dishes we ordered to truly bring out all the flavor to the food but not quite enough for me to shoot flames out of my mouth.  

Combined with the large open atmosphere and fast service, it made for a nice, spicy meal that warmed me up on a day which there were actual polar bear sightings in this part of town.

Well done Henry, well done.

PS try not to confuse the "Hunan" selections like Hunan fried rice or Hunan noodles with human fried rice/noodles as I did--you'll end up disappointed with the lack of cannibalism here..
author: Tien N.

description:
How convenient is it to find spicy hot chinese food right after happy hour. You can trip your way over from 111 Minna to Henry's Hunan. I think that might be the best part.

Here's what we had to absorb the alcohol:

- Onion Pancake: they fried this dough on both sides. Not exactly the way I imagined. A little too thin and not enough scallions.
- Hunan Pork Spare Ribs: Surprising that this wasn't spicy. Sauteed with onions and green peppers. Have to say a bit disappointed since it wasn't the fried kind with the thick sauce. This was more bland but the meat was tender.
- Kung Pao Chicken: Where did all the peanuts go? Not to mention the chicken? Really small pieces of chicken. A bit too oily. Spicy.
- Ma Po Tofu: Pretty authentic, spicy tofu with ground pork. Very good.
- String Bean with Shrimp: By far the favorite and servings of green bean were generous (though not the shrimp).
- Rice: $1.25 per person

My mouth was on fire for most of the dinner. And I'm sure my arteries are a little more clogged from the amount of oil in my food. Nonetheless, it was the kind of food that made you keep eating and wanting more. Great for groups to share.

Note: We didn't get any cut oranges or fortune cookies at the end of the meal. Sux.
author: Cindy W.

description: Took in Henry's as part of a hosted event, so we got to try a number of Henry's dishes. Henry's serves some decent Chinese. And the restaurant is very large and well suited for groups. However, it's also in an alley and not supremely easy to find. My only caution for Henry's was the our host asked them to hold back on the salt and MSG for the group's meals. I don't know if they did, but if so, the food was still rather salty.
author: David H.

description:
I came here despite some pretty bad reviews I read, mostly because I'm a fan of bad chow mein. Well, it ended up being ... different. For about $8, I got a big styrofoam thing to go, and it ended up lasting me 3 lunches. This was partially because the paper plates at my office are tiny, and partially because some sauce spilled out of the container and all over the inside of the bag (hence the paper plates), so dealing with it was a hassle. Of course, I'm not counting this against them.

The chow mein itself was OK, but not quite what I was expecting in the vein of bad Chinese food. Don't get me wrong; it was "bad," but not what I'm used to.

The service was very friendly.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Yummy , reasonably priced and quick! I usually walk in and order my lunch to go and it's not a long wait at all. The best deals are the lunch specials. The kung pao chicken is usually what I order - the lunch special comes with rice. I've also had the garlic chicken which is bomb, but you can't get it as a lunch special. 

Portions are huge, so either share or you'll have leftovers for dinner or the next day. When you order it spicy it really is spicy, which I love.

The place isn't fancy or anything, but what matters is the food!
author: Melissa C.

description:
I called them at 3:00 on Friday to schedule a reservation for 15 at 7:00 on Saturday night.  No problem.

When we arrived, we asked them to just bring us enough food to feed everyone.  We also asked for some stuff without shellfish or pork for the koshers (obviously not that kosher).

The food is good and spicy.  It does no favors for my stomach, but if I avoided food that ruined me, I'd be stuck eating brown rice and tofu.  

The shrimp and bean curds are delicious.

You HAVE TO order the meat pie!!  I could live on that stuff...seriously.

The best part is that at the end of the meal, after 4 appetizers, 10 main dishes, and 4 pitchers, the cost came out to only $25 per person.  It doesn't get betting than that.
author: Zak D.

description: Henry's is that classic Chinese restaurant in the sense that it's frenetic and has minimal ambiance.  WHO CARES?!! I dig the food. Their Hot and Sour soup is consistently good and really hits the mark.  The place is always efficient getting food out.  The servers are nice.  Where's Lou?  I like also the Kung Pao.  Good heat and good flavor.  Check them out!
author: Dan S.

description:
Ate at Henry's on a regular basis for some time before deciding maybe I deserve better. Some of the dishes are okay so it is not a bad option for take out. But the service is pretty horrible. No attention to detail be it dipping sauces for the Onion Cakes or getting orders taken in a timely fashion , there were times that the wait after being seated exceeded 15+ minutes just to have an order taken.

It is probably the fault of the customers that continue to return and deal with the horrible service but it is the only sit down Chinese restaurant of size in that small area around New Montgomery. For me that means going to other places rather then deal with the poor services and mediocre food.

Though I would rather walk an extra block and eat at Canton Dim Sum & Seafood Restaurant , this is a restaurant that actually cares about its customers.
author: Joseph A.

description:
If you are craving for extremely greasy Chinese food, then this is the right place to go!

The service is horrible and it takes a long time to get a seat and the food takes even longer to come out from the kitchen.
author: Beena A.

description:
Ehhhh. Cheap, good selection, and the food is pretty spicy. 

3 stars for the food

- 1 star for the service, as the waiter hovered over my table like a vulture once I finished eating, even though the restaurant was completely empty... I guess he wanted MY specific seat?!
author: Joanne T.

description:
There's nothing wrong with a meal and Henry's Hunan, I just don't like it that much.  The food is affordable and they give large portion sizes.  The ability to pick how spicy you want your food is also a bonus.

That said, the plates I've tried just didn't do anything for me.  One was too salty and other time it was too bland.  Maybe I'm just ordering the wrong items but nothing works for me.

They have decent lunch crowds here and can accommodate large groups, so they must be doing something right, just not for me.
author: Jared W.

description:
Henry's has the benefit of being one of my favorite type of food.  Hunan cuisine is HOT!!!  Hot as in SPICY and Hot as in GOOD.  I guess it could hurt Henry's that Hunan is one of my favorite things to eat too because I may be more picky with it but I felt it was very tasty.  I can usually eat very spicy but I have to admit, Henry's takes it to the limit with their chili peppers.  I may have to ask them to tone it down slightly next time.  But I will be back.  Maybe after 111 Minna since it is just a couple doorways down....  

Listen to some "Qool" Tunes and then have a Qool Meal after.......
author: Mark W.

description:
got the ma po tofu, the house special smoked meat, and a hot and sour soup.

i have to say it was pleasantly surprised. even tho it is not authentic like some places in richmond, it is also not one of those super americanized chinese either. 

for a quick and cheap lunch, i would probably come back.
author: Danielle A.

description: In 1974 Henry Chung founded his first Hunan restaurant in SF, bringing his own spin to dishes like Bean Curd with Meat Sauce, completely addictive and not  simple at all. The pot stickers are Gyoza style. I guarantee that you won't find this level of delicacy, complexity, and thrift outside China or at least Flushing, Queens. Diana's Special Meat Pie is enough for two people, and I heart the chicken salad. Some anonymous internet jokesters scoff at the service, but do you really need somebody asking how you're doing every two and a half minutes? Get help!
author: Jennifer W.

description: The food is good - had the dumplings and harvest pork today.  However, the service SUCKS.  Be prepared to spend an hour to an hour & a half for lunch.
author: John V.

description:
I'm surprised by the mixed reviews here, because I've eaten at Henry's for lunch about once a week for the past six months, and it has been very consistent and good. I've tried almost everything on the menu, and keep coming back to the glass noodles and the shredded pork.

Service has been OK each time I've gone.

I recommend eating family style here -- this might be why I don't notice the service problems others have mentioned. When you've got six people  and six orders, you're going to get at least one or two of those pretty quickly.

UPDATE - yep, Family style is the solution. I paid attention to service today, and they bring out each dish when it's done. Our first one came maybe 5-7 minutes before the last one arrived.

UPDATE 2 - OK, today the food took an ultra-long time. I've got to mark them down a star for not getting food to the table in a timely manner.
author: Pat T.

description:
The best chinese food ever!!!!
 I don't know if its a blessing or a curse to have this place be so close to where I work. 
 I always over order at this place. Everything I have had here is AMAZING!!!!  The kung pao shrimp, kung pao chicken, the velvet chicken, the chow mein, the string beans, the eggplant, the spicy fish dish, and esp. the "hunan special orange sauce chicken" all are the BEST EVER!!

 Don't bother dressing up, or even nice, they will serve you either way. This is also a great place to go after happy hour to soak up all the alcohol in your stomach with grease and carbs! yay!

Everyone has a favorite chinese place that they think is better than all others, but my Fav. Chinese place can kick your fav chinese place's ass any day!
author: Marlene D.

description:
service is HORRID.  Last time I went, we waited about 50 minutes for two dishes.  And only when my date asked the waiter "Hey, where's our food?" - at minute 40), did they bother to tell us "Oh, two cooks called in sick, so it will take a while"
atmosphere = bad
but hey, my kung pao wasn't SO bad....
author: Meg W.

description:
Good, greasy, gone! I enjoy the delicious meat pie so much that I really should make a meal of it. The Polish Sausage is two kinds of spicy good (but best divide up that mountain of meat). The hot and sour soup is odd but has become familiar. 

Huge tables and reservations after 1pm make this a good office outing.
author: Ashton E.

description: Decent chinese food. You gotta know what to order... the dishes are really hit or miss. Some dishes taste great while others not so great. There's quite a few asian fusion type of dishes in the menu like sasuage and veggies.
author: Steven B.

description: I came in for dinner tonight with my son. We came in at around 5:15 PM. It was slightly empty at the time, but there were a few folks here. I thought the service was great. I also thought the food was very good. Four stars from me for this little hole in the wall.
author: Jay B.

description:
This place always brings the following question to mind:  how do the Chinese stay slender eating this much grease?  They must be on to something I don't know about.

Aside from that, Henry's Hunan has good, spicy Chinese entrees.  I've eaten there several times with large groups of coworkers.  If you love spicy and you love Chinese, this is the place to check out.  The prices are very reasonable but make sure to make a reservation beforehand.  Usually the line wraps outside the restaurant a little before noon.

If you want upscale Chinese food, this is not the place for you.  But, if you're looking for a good, spicy meal to kick start your day, check it out.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Service is good, not as attentive as before. 
Quality of food however has gone down for the last couple of years.
We notice the portions get smaller, more vegetable in meat dishes.  Small shrimp replaces prawn, and immitation scallop in my favorite Henry's Special.
Prices haven't change much, probably should to maintain the quality.
author: Lawrence C.

description: You can't beat HH for a quick delicious well priced lunch, period!
author: Fred W.

description:
I usually frequent the one on Sansome but I don't see it listed here, but it doesn't really matter because they're all pretty much the same.  The food here is spicy, hearty, and served in good sized portions.   I always order either one of the cod dishes (oh so good) and my lady loves the way they make the curry chicken.  I also recommend to try Diana's Meat Pie which is always a nice way to start off a meal here.

If you like spicy chinese food, you'll love this place.
author: Ree-och G.

description:
It's a glorified Chinese takeout, that charges a premium for dishes that consists of cheap meats (ground pork), cheap vegetables (cabbage, carrots, and bamboo shoots), all drowned in a spicy Hunan sauce.  It's always greasy and never remotely healthy.  Yet, the place is always busy during lunch and is a landmark in SF.  And to confess, I actually like their food. 

Based on it's culinary significance in this city, and the addictive nature of their food (and it is addicting), Henry's gets a solid 3 stars from me.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
3-4 stars is about right.  I feel Henry's is a unique restaurant in that they appeal to both fan's of American-chinese food (e.g. sweet/sour pork, fried rice, etc...), as well as fan's of more authentic chinese cuisines.  There's something for everyone and the dishes are tasty, if not a bit salty.  Might I add that what many consider to be salty actually comes from the bean paste sauce, used a lot in Hunan food.  To that end, it's a bit deceiving and gives customers the wrong impression that their food is laced with salt.

The trademark with Henry's is that their dishes seem, feel, and taste fresh...a farmer's market of meats and vegetables.  Dishes come out full of fire and flavor, not soggy and drowned out.

I'd put these guys on a must try list.  Most 1-2 star reviews here pretty irrational.  If co-workers go their "regularly" then suffice to say one bad experience is likely an abberation.  Ditto with feeling sick, etc...  At worst they're decent with a fresh quality to it.  At best, they might be your new favorite fix.
author: Add M.

description:
There are so many Henry's around town now!  I remember when they just had one restaurant.  

The Kung Pao Chicken is still good, still spicy!  :)
author: Stitchy M.

description: We were barhopping in Soma. Were seated a table of 10 no problem on a Friday night.  Onion pancakes crispy but lacking any greenery. We ordered a selection of dishes, of varying spiciness. There wasn't much to differentiate dishes (ie various chopped meats with all the same brown sauce, it seemed) but it was satisfying and filling.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
I absolutely love Henry's, I love Henry's so much that every person on the staff in the restaurant knows my name and what i'm going to order. Sure the food can get greasy from time to time, and sure it's really heavy, but Henry's seriously is my staple for Chinese food. 

The prices here are decent, plus you get a ton of food which is great if you're with business partners or a large group of people. Parking is non existant, but that's to be expected because you're in the FiDi and the ambiance of the place is non existant as well. But if you're looking for some of the best Chinese food (in my opinion) in the FiDi, Henry's is the place for you.

Tips and Pointers:
-Try the dumplings
-Try #17 Beef with Tofu
-Diana's meat pie is amazing as well
-No Parking
-Prices are moderate
-Huge portions, open late.

[APPROVED]
author: Eric T.

description:
This review is based off four dishes at Henry's - of course, the best dishes.

Have only had these specific four dishes here, but can recommend them all.

There is this Annie's Pie or Special Pie thing that's made of pork, spices and lettuce, kinda looks like a Taco Bell Mexican Pizza, but is deliciously (I'm assuming very fattening) assembled for a group of six - really easy to share.

The spicy shrimp and green beans are also pretty killah. The spice burns a bit unless you request "medium hot".  They have a great sauce and aren't overly oily like a lot of Chinese food tends to be.

Then there are the dumplings - pork or chicken - I'll go with chicken.  They were really good and surprisingly light in flavor, none of that weird smelling funk pot stickers can sometimes have.

The Mu Shu Pork - I liked it, but the wrappers are most definitely microwaved because they start going really hard and crispy once they hit the table and they can sometimes tear when you pull them apart.

Best part of Henry's?  You'll never have to wonder whether or not your eating cat.
author: Lauren G.

description:
The food  was really good. Service was quick. They get packed but the huge line at the door went pretty fast.

The sweet & sour chicken was very tasty, good quality meat - not too sweet, it come with pineapples, onions and bell peppers. The portions are pretty big. The spring rolls were very good.

This place remind me of a Vegas buffet the way you line up to get a table and pay at the little window. They are efficient at getting folks in and out. I will be back - the food is great!

*** Not as good as my last trip. Their lunch menu got REALLY small and pathetic - nothing looks appealing at all. The sweet and sour chicken was soggy and seemed old. The service is lousy. This place is very average.
author: Chili B.

description: Muthafuggin Diana's Meat Pie ALLLLL DAY! oh and a pot of tea. Thats it for me...
author: Nick V.

description:
I was ready to give it three stars last night....until Howard's Special gave me the runs this morning.  Perhaps too much information, but wouldn't you rather know this sooner than later?

On a good note, the only thing I would come back for is the meat pie.
author: Andrea U.

description:
I've been working in SoMa for three years, but I haven't ate at the restaurant that's just down a block away from me, at Henry's, though I'd heard plenty of praises for it. "They have great chicken curry," says my friend, "and we have it every Thursdays at work. It's been a tradition, I guess." My friend either really, really loves Henry's, or doesn't know any other restaurants around work. 

So, here's a question: why is my friend so obsessed over Henry's that it makes him eat there, religiously, every Thursdays? Won't the food, uh, get boring after a while? Is the food at Henry's so arresting that it causes men to devote one -- one! -- day a week for Chinese food made only by a guy named Henry? (Well, nowadays, Henry's probably hasn't worked in the kitchen for a hella long time.)

Stepping into Henry's Hunan at the SoMa location on Natoma, I thought the place would be small, no bigger than B&M, the other Chinese restaurant by my work. But Henry's is huge, physically, and teeming in activity! Waiters frantically rush by you, holding trays of food and drinks in their hands while weaving in and out of the standing patrons; the large, loud open kitchen on the side of the room fills the restaurant with the chatter of Chinese cooks and the rumble of the woks over the flaming stoves; the loud discordant sound of silverware clanging against the plates and the deafening thumps of chopsticks hitting the white rice bowls.   

There was a line when we'd arrived at Hunan's, about 15 people ahead of us, but we were seated in less than 10 mins, thanks to Henry's spacious dining room filled with lots and lots of tables. Seated, we looked over the menu, found what we wanted, then waited for someone, anyone, to take our order. Five minutes passed. Then ten minutes. Still, nobody came to take our order as we sat there, speechless, at the the staff's oversight.

Finally, a waiter, or maybe it was the busboy, walks by, takes our order, and runs off to the kitchen. About 15 mins later, the food arrives one after the other, each plate steaming hot, fresh from kitchen. 

Here's what we ordered:

Garlic Chicken:  The title gives this dish's flavor away: garlic, lots of it. Diced chicken covered in a soy and sugar sauce.The portions were generous, for sure, but the sauce was a overpowering. 

Country Style Vegetables: A mix medley of vegetables of questionable quality. Soft and mushy, the country style vegetables was the least favorite of the dishes, simply because of the underwhelming taste, gross texture, and undesirable palette of soggy vegetables in sauce unidentified and mysterious to even its cooks. 

Chicken with String Beans: Diced chicken in a soy sauce marinade served over a bed of crispy string beans. I loved this dish for the delicious string beans, not for the chicken, which wasn't that great. I wouldn't get this dish again, but I would order a dish solely for string beans.

Vegetarian Egg Rolls: Meh. Stringed vegetables including carrots, stuff, and other weird stuff, wrapped in a flour roll, flash fried until the outer layer turns a yellow or gold, whichever comes first. The title is a misnomer, though, since the there was no egg in this roll. Only vegies in a averagely made roll. Not worth the money, totally.

 I felt lethargic and tired after I'd ate the meal, like a lazy-ass sloth lolling in the trees. Of course, I'm the one to blame as I gorged my poor stomach on Chinese Food, spiking my system with excessively dangerous levels of MSG. Knowing full well that I may end up dead at my desk the next time I go to Henry's, would I come here again? Hrm, not really. The service is hit or miss, and the atmosphere is too noisy for a nice, relaxing hour on lunch. Takeout, perhaps? Yeah, I'll just get everything to-go, just like my obsessive friend.
author: Richard L.

description:
Great for lunch out of the office.  I used to get take out from here as it gets busy during peak lunch times.  Chinese favs include dumplings and the noodles w beef stew.  The chicken was good too--spicy.
I've had similar dishes at other restaurants so nothing really stood out.
author: Eric Y.

description:
I came here and ate way too much. I was with a group of 10 people, and we seemed to think that 20 courses were in order. Like we had never seen family style portions before, didn't know what we were in for. Oaf. Suffice it to say, I spent the next two hours trying to pack it up pack it in... It was all very tasty, particularly the pork dumplings and the hot and sour soup. 

There was one dish -- I think it was Henry's Special -- that was particularly good. Hot with spice, meaty (great mix of chicken, shrimp, pork), with a great sauce. Mmmm. 

We arrived at 11:45, and it was packed but we had a reservation. I suggest coming after the lunch rush. That way you can focus on the food, chat and linger.
author: Cleo B.

description:
This place serves food with a bunch of hair in it.

I work right by this place, and stopped by to get an order of spring rolls. I walked back into work and opened the box, pulled out one of the pre-cut spring rolls, only to find multiple black hairs in it.

Enjoy.
author: Tar d.

description:
It ain't gourmet, but it is consistently tasty, hot, well-priced. 
Service is swift and hopping considering it gets jam packed every workday lunch hour.
Noodles are good, smoked ham dish is something my friend eats like once every week minimum, meat pie is good, overall a solid bet and a good for large groups too.
author: H H.

description:
3.5 - docking 1/2 star because after the dumplings, it took forever for the food to come.

As a kid, I'd always pass a huge red Henry Hunan's sign on the way to grandma's. She's gone now but the sign endures, so when a coworker suggested this place I was excited to try the food keeping these restaurants in business.

It's good! Lots of flavor and dayum, they don't kid around when you order something spicy hot. We had to get extra napkins because we were sweating from the Kung Pao Shrimp. Lots of red chilis, their seeds, and chili oil. The Chicken with Green Beans isn't as hot, but was delicious. You definitely need rice to go with the strong flavors.

Notes:
-No chow fun here (flat rice noodles), only chow mein and the thinner noodles.
-Large portions. Pack up the rice with your leftovers.
-Get the dumplings, 'cause they're tender and porky inside. Not fried but drizzled in sauce.
-There's a back and front entrance. Place spans the width of the block.
-First Chinese restaurant I've been to where the menu was only in English. Some surprising menu items.  "Diana's Special Meat Pie" has parmesan cheese in it?
-Large, mostly non-Asian lunch crowd. All Chinese no-nonsense wait staff and chefs.
-Open kitchen. You'll smell like Hunan food when you leave. Mmm...
-Please feed me faster next time
author: Amy N.

description:
Diana's Meat Pie
Marty's Special
Braised String Beans

What else do you need? And dinner is never crowded at this location.
author: Pete W.

description:
How surprising to find my all-time favorite mu shu pork ever at Henry's Hunan. 

We eat here all the time, at least once a week, since it's (a) a block from my office, (b) cheap, (c) extremely generous with portion size's, and (d) my regular lunch companion's favorite place. So by the time I got to mu shu, I'd tried many, many things on the menu. I was bored with it all so just for the heck of it, I turned to that old standby from the 70's. And got the best I had ever had. Yum.

Many other good things here. I love the Diana's meat pie and the string beans with anything. 

Not the best Chinese food I have ever had, but it usually hits the spot. The service is nearly always excellent, too. Extra half-star for that.

Tip: even as big as it is, this place fills up early for lunch on weekdays, especially Fridays. If you show up after 11:50 or so, be prepared for a wait.
author: David G.

description: Been eating at different Henry's  Hunan restaurants for years and sooo enjoy the food! What baffles me is why people come here and order standard american chinese dishes.This is food from  the hunan region of China people...not Canton. One orders the specialties of the region,not sweet and sour pork.The stand outs are all the salads,onion cakes,meat pies,hot and sour dishes,smoked dishes and some others. If you ask your server,they will tell you what they are.We always order the spice level at medium.,so yummy! That said,the eggplant salad,chicken salad,hot and sour anything,smoked ham & chicken,Marty's special and curry chicken.There are so many more too numerous to list.
author: Andee F.

description:
This is my favorite place to have lunch with my dad.  We love love love it.  The only negative thing I could ever think to say about it is that sometimes you have to wait a long time for a table at noon, because it is so good.  Dinner time is pretty empty, though, so that's a good time to go and avoid the rush.  
I order the exact same thing almost every time I go there - beef with bean curd and the dry sauted string beans, but other dishes I would recommend are Marty's special, Diana's special meat pie, Henry's special, the shrimp with bean curd, and hot and sour soup.  
This is my favorite location of the chain, but the one on Sansome Street is good too.
author: Claire T.

description:
I have been going to this place for more than five years and I can't believe how low people are rating this place. I would comeback from college for the weekend just to go to this place. 

The waiters and hostess are great. There is this one waiter, I call him Marty, after the Marty special. This guy is so funny, it is hard to understand what he is saying, but still the guy is great although not their best waiter.

After going here for years, this is what I always order and I suggest you try:

Dumplings
Hot and Sour Chicken
Marty Special
Combo Chow Mein

Anything else is up to you but to me, those are the best things on the menu.

Fridays at lunch time it is always packed so either have an early or late lunch.
author: Bryan K.

description:
Henry's Hunan is the best Chinese restaurant I have ever been to. If you like spicy food, you wont find a better place. The Kung 
Pao Chicken is like no other! i could eat it every day. If you dont like spicy food, get the broccoli with beef and everyone must try the famous meat pie (its much better than it sounds).
author: Chris P.

description: Service has gotten better the last two times I came, but try and avoid the rush.  Try the absolutely sinful meat pie - fried goodness!  A lot of their chicken dishes are great and no matter what, there is always leftovers because they serve you so much food.  I'm starting to like this place more and more...
author: Brian S.

description:
Not the best Chinese food I have ever had but then again it is not your typical Cantonese or Mandarin cuisine I am used to. Had the hot and sour chicken which was alright. 

I only came here to try something new as pretty much every eating establishment around FiDi and SOMA have been tried since I began working. I'll give it one more pass...
author: S L.

description:
I don't understand how people could not like this place. Dumplings, stellar. Spicy rock cod fillets are the stuff of legend. The ham and string beans makes regular apperances in my dreams, and usually after making love to a super model we feed each other the smokey spicy goodness. I have never, read NEVER been disappointed at any of their locations. 

Some folks were complaining about how the food comes out or the service, but the food comes out when it is cooked and it is hot. The service is very matter of fact. I have been to places with much worse service. 

Henry is an old reliable for me and I will always love it.
author: Seth H.

description: Bout time we found really decent Chinese food delivery in SOMA!  Those dumplings are addictive, and for the 1st time we ordered non-Hunan spicy, and were really happy - and full.  Delivery was really fast too.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Weekday lunch crowd is always at this hot hunan spot downtown. Get there @12 or suffer a wait. Meat pie and orange chicken are a must, get some green beans on the side and call yourself happy! Better order everything at once as the wait staff is not the most attentive. Overall good lunch spot. Have been many times.
author: Mel H.

description: Good veggie and fish dishes. Brown rice too. I liked the fun commotion and we didn't have too wait at all. Impressed with the price too.
author: Scott D.

description:
It's my first review, so why not start with an all time favorite? Henry's Hunan. I always order the same thing: Marty's Special: ham, chicked, peppers, onions, red pepper, bamboo shoots. Oh my god is it good. Salty vs. spicy.

When I go with others I get rock cod, beef string beans, or, if with someone from Chicago, Hunan kielbasa, yes it's good.

Go before noon or expect to wait. Wait staff surly and spotty, but I'm not here for the ambieance. Don't even think about kitchen clenliness (it isn't).
author: Eric W.

description: This place (while - yes, it's busy - but only because it's delicious) is soooo yummy.  I'm normally not the biggest fan of Chinese food, but I love Henry's.
author: MacKenzie P.

description: Really good food with really bad service.  I've actually gotten to the point where I look forward to the horrible service when I go to this place.  If you want a fork, really, bring your own because your server will never bring one.  The meat pie is sinfully good.  The smoked pork dishes are great.  the Tofu with meat is really good as well.
author: Nedra D.

description: Good for lunch. I got the smoked pork lunch special for about $7 including tax. I probably would not order that again as it was very salty, but I'll give other menu items a shot.
author: Ava C.

description: We tried this place twice and not impressed at all.  I tried most of the featured items here on yelp such as the Diana's Meat Pie and the Kung Pao chicken. We also tried the beef fried rice which was good only after we added some soy sauce to it.  The portions are pretty generous though.
author: G A.

description:
ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!?

So... most of the guys in my office (non-chinese) all say this place is great.  My grandma's from Hunan.   I know hunan food.  I'm skeptical, it being in the SOMA/financial district.  I check out some menus online and such, and... I see this dumpling in beef soup dish on the menu!  I'm so happy!  i haven't seen this dish in the states YET, as it's taiwanese street food.  Most people don't do it because the dumplings have to have a flavor that can match the beef stew flavor.  So I order it from henry's.  Pick it up and take it back to the office to eat it.  IT SUCKED.  Dumplings were standard boiled dumplings (would be OK by themselves), and DID NOT match the beef soup.  SOUP WAS GREASY AS ALL HELL  ("Excuse me, I think you should have used 10W-30 instead of this 10W-50"). HOW DO YOU SCREW THIS UP?!  At the very least, you just throw some beef stew on top of dumplings.  Beef stew was ALMOST CLEAR (should be a dark opaque brown), bland, with no chili oil.  BEEF STEW AND DUMPLINGS.  WTF?  I had to FORCEFEED the rest of it.  

So then a few months later, my boss decides to take us all out for lunch.  He chooses Henry's.  He knows my reservations about the place, and insists that I do all the ordering.  No problem.

I sit down with the menu and try to piece together a meal for about 12 of us.  God this was some of the worst shit I've had in a long time.  I'm talking to the waitress in chinese trying to figure out stuff to order that would not make me puke.  I ask them for potato strands stir-fried with peppers (a hunan CLASSIC my grandma taught me).  nope.  I asked for a lamb chop.  nope.  I wanted to order a bean sauce (dou ban) whole fish to go with the meal, given the large amount of people, but they don't have whole fish.  At all.  And she looks very apologetic and explains to me that "THEY DON'T MAKE FOOD FOR CHINESE PEOPLE".  That was awesome, I couldn't believe she actually said the words!  She was hard pressed to find anything for me to order too.  I ended up just picking random crap after choosing a few decent looking dishes.

Everything was way too greasy. Flavor balance was passable, spiciness was COMPLETELY LACKING.  The only dish that was not crappy was the hunan smoked/ salted pork belly meat dish (which was actually spicy too).  I would say it was actually decent.  Not enough to increase my rating though.   And the kung pao chicken was passable (read:  NOT HOT ENOUGH, but not too sweet, and at least there were no vegetables in it).

Summary:  BAD AMERICANIZED CHINESE.  THIS IS NOT HUNAN FOOD.

Please.  Someone.  Open a real chinese restaurant in the financial district?  There are MORE than enough asians around to appreciate the REAL food!  The only one right now is Tea Garden.  But I get tired of eating their 3 varieties of taiwanese street food...

(fyi, yeah I screwed up the first time and posted to another SOMA henry's location...haha)

(edit 2008:  had to add a star back because at the very least, henry's is better than pile of shit house of nanking, piece of shit mandarin gourmet, and other shitty americanised chinese)
author: Fong L.

description: Not sure why but my coworkers love this place...well, I guess none of them really knows what authentic Chinese food entails.(half of them are from South Africa)  Let me tell you -- Henry's Hunan is definitely NOT authentic Chinese.  It's not even American Chinese.  I would take Panda Express over this ANY DAY.  I've had better Chinese food in Salt Lake City, Utah.  The only thing that's edible at this place is the dipping sauce for their steamed dumplings.  Well, I have to admit the rice is pretty good also.  I never appreciated rice as much as I did when I was at Henry's Hunan...I used the rice to soak up the loads of grease from the dishes.  I refuse to go back to Henry's Hunan...not over my dead body.
author: Winnie L.

description:
This was my 2nd time at Henry's Hunan. This time there was no turny-table :( The food is aiight. I feel like this is one of those asian places that caters to non-asian crowds. Yes it is clean, service is fast, but the portions are kind of small. i like giant portions cuz i eat a lots.  Prices start around 10 dollars for the most basic chinese foods, I dont feel like you get much bite for your buck here. There menu is small and nothing really unique.
Still IT IS the fidi, so its not a bad place to go if you dont want to make that trek closer to Chinatown. The waitress brought us a giant mountain of rice (really wayyyy too much) and never brought us the brown rice we ordered--yet we were charged for it! Yet its so busy that none of us even bothered to dispute it. Too much of a hassle! The family style thing is always fun tho and its a big place so convienent and if you work in the fidi, even more so! 

 I do however, like the little chili-men on their bowls- how cute!
author: Amy S.

description: I've been here a couple times, and came away unimpressed both times.  The cooking itself was decent (good dumplings), but most of the dishes were served way too salty for my taste.
author: Rusty S.

description:
I am a chinese so I am very picky when it comes to chinese food. I've been to Hunan several times, food isn't bad, but I don't understand why they call themselves "hunan"restaurant" since the food isn't Hunan at all.

Overall it's not a bad place for a OK meal, but if you are seeking for decent Hunan food, I won't recommand it.
author: Echo C.

description: Horrible! The folks at my office swear by this place and I cannot for the life of me understand why. Everything is salty and spicy. Overly seasoned to the point that its almost unrecognizable.
author: Louie C.

description: Way too much corn starch in the dishes and hot and sour soup.  Difficult to understand why this place is always so crowded!
author: shaun l.

description: The best kung pao chicken in SF.  I've tried many other restaurants, and Henry's is #1.  Not all locations though.  The Natoma St. location is the best.  The Sacramento St. location used to have good kung pao chicken, but hasn't for a few years now.  I've walked 15 minutes out of the way to get to this location for lunch - it is that good!
author: Boomer D.

description: Another trip to Henry's.  Aspargus chicken was delicious!   Service was the usual quick to take the orders and dump the food out.  Otherwise, you need to chase them down for anything!
author: I have something to say... A.

description:
i got a taste of 12 different dishes thanks to wonderful colleagues who let me stick my fork into everything :) 

i thought everything tasted pretty good!  :) i love love their super spicy mongolian beef with rice (one of my FAV foods of all time).  

i love love love the way they "speed" up service for me -- at first they told me i had to wait 20min. but they took pity on me when i said "but i'm really hungry....x_x...." and i got my order in about 5 min :P i LOVE "customer service agents" who are  flexible ^.^!! 

sad to say, they lost "two stars" because the 3rd time (in a week) that i went back for the same mongolian beef with rice, the standard dropped so much, i was instantly cured of my addiction to the dish. 

maybe they changed the cook? maybe they changed the cow? i don't know. i'm miserable. i thought i had found the BEST mongolian beef dish that would offer me comfort in the colder weather to come......only to be let down by their lack of consistency..*sob*
author: Purple B.

description: Been to Henry's Hunan 4-5 times, and regretted it every time.  The food is mediocre, and very greasy and salty.  Service quality fluctuates - had to wait once for like 45 minutes for the food to arrive, though other times service has been great.
author: Dinesh M.

description: This is considered good Chinese food to the unadventurous Gringo. A previous Yelper mentioned that all the food has the same flavor which I totally agree with. Also, they use wayyyyy too much salt. I remember my old roommate used to rave about this place. He falls into that previously stated category. The Samson location gets the same rating.
author: Ericka A.

description:
I've gone here since I was a little girl and I never go more than a few weeks without eating here.  While their take-out is perfect for a fabulously quick, inexpensive meal during my lunch hour, it is always a treat to have dinner at this gem of a hunan joint, hidden in an alley off New Montgomery St.

  While the faint of heart may need to ask for reduced oil or mild spice, each of their dishes is mouth-wateringly delicious, like nothing I've eaten at any other chinese eatery.  I highly recommend Diana's meat pie (not exactly authentic chinese fare, but who cares? it's amazing), their dumplings (not pot stickers, mind you), and absolutely anything with their smoked ham (smoked ham with green beans is my favorite, but Marty's Special never ceases to amaze), as well as the hot & spicy rock cod fillets (om nom nom).  

  There will always be a place in my heart for the delightfully spicy and unique food, as well as the sweet, efficient, and generous staff, at Henry's Hunan -- you must try it!
author: Tessa O.

description: For those working downtown, you will eventually find yourself eating with what seems like everyone else working downtown. Very casual and hectic, but fairly decent food. Excellent for a Tuesday group lunch.
author: Philip M.

description: I have gone to this restaurant many times over the past 25 years, but when I took my family and small grandchildren there for dinner recently, I don't know which was worse, the food or the service.  They put us into the very back corner, far away from the other diners, and then ignored us the rest of the night.  We asked for mild food for the children, and the only thing mild was the rice.  Everything was tasteless, too hot, or just overcooked.   I've eaten broccoli beef more times than I can count in my lifetime, but this was so hot, it was barely edible.  We honestly wondered if they spiked the food because they didn't want us there.  None of us will ever go back.  Too bad.
author: Pamela G.

description: Wow, I can't believe it's taken me so long to try this place. Probably because it's tucked away in an alley, which makes it seem like it might be a scary hole in the wall, but it's actually kind of nice inside. Easily the best non-dim sum chinese food in downtown SOMA that I've tried so far. Portions are large, ingredients appear to be quality, and it was pretty tasty (kung pao pork). Service was a little slow, but it was prime lunch rush. I'll have to try calling ahead and ordering take out some time.
author: Tom H.

description: my friend introduced me to this location in 2000. LOVE IT! the family and staff are very friendly and just nice people. Frank always takes care of me and remembers my favorites. We go every Tuesday for lunch and the whole staff smiles and says "hello, Monica, is Katie coming?", haa.  The food is YUMMY IN MY TUMMY! Tonight I had what will probably be my last order of Hunan Bacon :(. They decided to take it off the menu because people were complaining that is was too fatty or hot, silly people. It's an excellent dish and if you order something with "Hunan" and "bacon" in the title, well you should expect fat and chili peppers! But, I digress, the food is wonderful and cooked fresh to order. Many dishes have lots of ginger, mmmmm. My favorites are House Bean Curd, Dumplings, Onion Cake, Chicken Salad and of course Hunan Bacon(now off the menu)
author: Monica H.

description: Whether for lunch or dinner, I've never been disappointed in Henry's on Natoma. The service is great and the food even better! And Frank at the front is amazing. Can get really busy during the lunch hour, but it's worth the wait and, even when it's busy, I'm usually in and out in an hour.
author: Katie U.

description: The food and service is OK, and I would venture to say it's overrated.  I've only been here for lunch, as it's in the downtown area.  At first glance, the dishes look disturbingly alike (same sauce different ingredients?). Their lunch specials are affordable and with a larger group, you won't pay much eating family style.  I did try their smoked ham dish and the ham is really good.  I also do recommend the Henry's Shredded Pork dish.  It's the closest thing to a Chinatown type restaurant in the area, thus the long lunch wait.
author: Adrian N.

description: Go for lunch on a weekday and you'll be in a line wrapped around the corner.  Go on a Saturday and you'll be the only one in there.  But whenever you go you're going to be impressed.  Perfect on a chilly day with some hot, spicy soup.  Even when packed to the rafters, Henry's is fast in service and reasonable in price.
author: Rob M.

description: An institution where the waiters won't make eye contact for the first 6 years that you go there.  The daily lunch specials with a cup of hot and sour soup for under $10 are the way to go for me.  It helps that I work around the corner.  Order the Kung Pao Chicken spicy if you like the hot poops.
author: Lemmy C.

description: Slow service, rice that tasted horrible. Very annoying waiters. Wont be coming back.
author: Rubin S.

description: Went to lunch at Henry's on Natoma yesterday with couple of friends who work in the area.  I have eaten at this restaurant 6 or 7 times over the years.  I like the industrial decor, one wall is brick, open kitchen.  We beat the crowd by arriving at 11:30 but by 12:30 there was a line of 6 or so people at the hostess station waiting.  Agree with many reviewers that service can be slow and the wait staff seems to rotate making it difficult to get questions answered.  As for the food, we ordered ma po tofu, Henrys Special and Napa cabbage with prawns. The dishes all were tasty, shrimp super fresh, (Henry Special is a seafood combo with veggies) my primary complaint is that all seem to use the same base sauce.  Everything kind of has the same flavor.  Bill came to under $45 for the three of us.  I think there are better choices out there.  Parking as noted is tough, the great city of San Francisco now has street meter parking at $3.50 an hour if you can find a spot.  Still better than local parking lots which want your pink slip and first born.
author: Jeff R.

description: Aaron V. took me here to grab some lunch grub.  Off the beaten path, not quite obvious where it is, so keep your eyes open down what looks like an alley near Howard.  The ordering is a little confusing because of the layout, I didn't know if I was placing a bet in a horse race or ordering food from the cashier, but the food was good.  I don't know if I'd go here by myself, but if someone in the office was to say that's where they're going, I'd tag along.
author: Andy B.

description: Henry's gets a "4" on the Dumplings alone.  wow.  They can be a bit surprising at first if you're used to the more fried kind with a dipping sauce.  I don't know how they are served inside, but to go they come in a little carton partly swimming in the sauce - which was a turn off at first, until I found out - much to my amazement - that the sauce wasn't overpowering or sweet, but just right and nicely spicy.  Fried rice is a bit bland.  Otherwise, it's reliable basic hunan cooking.
author: J P.

description: On my last day of work at my SOMA job, a couple coworkers and I had lunch here.  It was Friday and we should have come right when it opened at 11:30 because it was super busy at 11:45.  I am a big fan of the dumplings and the noodles here (liang mien and the hunan noodles).  Everything else has the same 3 sauces.  I think they are also fairly  liberal with the MSG so I'd beware...
author: Mitzi C.

description: The sea food dishes here are really good.  Love the spicy scallops.  Very nice servers
author: Loren L.

description: The other reviews on this place are hit or miss.  Yes the food is salty and can be spicey.  The spicy cod rocks my boat as does the shrimp and string beans.  If you need a third dish go with the mongolian beef followed by curry chicken and then some form of tofu.  Ofcouse there's always a coworker who bitches about the shit being too spicy or salty. ....just say mo sahpicey and it'll just go down betta....Probably not a good place for a date
author: Summit S.

description: I love Henry's.  It's a great cheap lunch spot and I come here at least twice a month.  Likes: the famous meat pie, glass noodles, noodles with special sauce and the kung pao chicken.  This place gets really packed that's why I'm so suprised with all of the bad reviews. Someone forwarded me this site which shows pictures and reviews of most of the dishes...http://greasepig.com/henrys/
author: Lauren S.

description:
is it just me or doesn't it seem like anytime a hole-in-the-wall restaurant branches out to other, oftentimes bigger and nicer, outposts, the "upgrade" in decor/size/location often result in a "downgrade" in quality of food?

yes, the natoma location is much larger than the henry's i first discovered on sacramento street - banquet hall-sized even.  and the decor is a step up (which isn't saying much) - exposed brick walls, high ceilings, open kitchen, even a few (fake?) palm trees.  but it gets just as busy (there's a line by 12:00) and service is just as slow or even non-existent.  it once took over 45 minutes for our party of 4 to be served the first dish we ordered during the lunch rush.  

maybe i'm just biased but i swear the food isn't as good as it is at the sacramento spot - kung pao isn't as spicy, noodles are a little greasier...but it's still decent downtown lunchfare, especially considering the bargain prices.
author: Jen P.

description: My coworkers and I always go to Henry's when we are craving chinese food. I would give the place 5 stars but there is one beef I have with Henry's, the service can be poor there. We all order at the same time and everyones dishes come out at separate times. Sometimes, during the lunch rush, it can take an unreasonable amount of time to place and get your order so we have learned to go after 1pm to avoind any lag time. Other than that, the food is excellent! It is so hard to find good chinese food but this is definitely one of the best places I have been to in San Francisco.
author: Jessica E.

description:
This is one of several family restaurants of Henry Chung's Hunan Restaurant that popularized Hunanese food throughout the United States. It's run by Frank, his grandson, and their extended family. My high rating is for the combination of friendly, personal service and excellent food. 

Some of the diners here have given mercilessly low ratings that don't really give this place a chance to show what it can do. C'mon folks, Hunan food is a bit different than the usual Chinese fare. It's country style cooking. Also, the place is very busy during lunch hour, a testament to its renown but also it's a little hard at that time to get to know the family that runs this place.

The staff here, Lina (Frank's lovely wife), Kathy, Lorna, Rachel, Judy, and others will help you choose something to your taste, whether you want something that's intensely hot and sticks to the ribs, soup, seafood, or vegetarian. And if you have special dietary needs like I do, they'll do everything they can to meet them. If you show up at non-peak hours, they're friendly and will chat. Before I knew I had dietary restrictions, I tried many things on their menu but since then often bring my friends who can order freely (yes I do still taste my old favorites!) and they're still cooking to the same high standards. 

Try for instance Marty's Special, or some of their unique smoked dishes or the cold chicken salad or eggplant salad that are featured in Henry's Hunan cookbook. I also really like the squid with black bean sauce and an old favorite was the deep friend onion cakes. But everything's good. 

Let your needs be known, get to know this family, and they'll treat you like a welcome guest. This has been one of my favorites since the 1970s and I'm delighted to keep coming back.
author: Gary S.

description: I love going to this place. Can get pretty crowded during lunch. If I'm downtown and have a lunch meeting with my boss, this is where we go. Something I tried and really enjoyed lately is the meat pies. Tasty, but keep in mind they're different from meat pies in New Zealand. Roll in with friends, family, or work mates and chow down family style :)
author: John B.

description: I've been coming here since I worked at 544 Mission in 1999(now the JP Morgan Chase building)   Excellent dumplings-order the garlic chicken and vegetarian string beans.  There are three locations in the city-the one on Sansome sucks.
author: Beth V.

description:
I had a very annoying experience with this restaurant recently. I ordered for delivery at 6:50p in the evening. It was very difficult to communicate my address because we live in a new neighborhood but they took the address anyway. After 40 min they called to take the address again clearly they didn't understand it in the first place (but they didn't say thay they didn't). I explained again but I couldn't explain my location hence gave a nearby location which is easy to understand. They said it will be another 20min which is fine. After 30 min I received another call from the delivery person again asking for directions clearly with no idea where I am. At that point we said if he doesn't arrive in 10 min we didn't want to food any more it was already 1 hour 10 min and I didn't know how long more this could take. He told me fine and didn't come. 
This was annoying but OK we live in a new neighborhood.. The real annoying part is that at 8:33 the restaurant calls me, he is upset because we didn't want the food. He claimed that the delivery person arrived and called us at the address and waited for us, in turn we refused to buy it which was a complete lie! I told him that when I last spoke with his delivery guy I gave him directions. He never told me that he has arrived. But he wouldn't believe me, he kept repeating the same thing. The truth is he probably never came here.

 I was extremely annoyed by this place. You should expect a very **rude and unprofessional** treatment if you order from them.
author: erdem u.

description: I really want to like Henry's, it's pretty good Chinese but nothing outstanding. It's always packed at lunch, and unfortunately somewhat disorganized (we ordered two dishes, our garlic chicken arrived, we waited another 10 minutes for the second entree).
author: Nish N.

description: Why people gave this place a bad rating is beyond me.  I've been a loyal fan for over 10 years (I prefer the Byrant street location). This is some of the most creative chinese in the city.  Most chinese restarants serve bland, boring "american-like" food.  Not here--sure, the service may be a bit dicey (most often during the lunch rush) but the food is much better than many of the people below say.  For a unique dish, order the Hot and Sour Chicken or Hunan Prawns.  Ok, it's a bit spicy but the food is fresh-- you see them making dumplings there everyday.  Prices are good for the location.  Enough said...
author: Brian M.

description: (Friday) lunch with 3 friends.  Short-ish wait to get seated, long-ish wait to get served.  #26 Spicy & Hot Rock Cod Fillet: 10 firm pieces of fish.  Good, but nothing special.  #58 Liling Bean Threads: thin rice vermicelli with some sprouts.  Wish there had been a description.  #60 Hunan Bacon: spicy pork belly & tofu in a broth.  Spicy and tender.  If you don't like the feel of pork blubber in your mouth, this will be very challenging to eat.  Steamed rice: not fluffy at all.  This was actually very disappointing AND they charge extra for it?!  I guess the nice thing about it was that it ended up being ~$10/person.
author: Anonymouse C.

description: Okay, so all over the restaurant is plastered "Zagat Rated".  So how many stars did Zagat rate it? It is okay chinese food. But VERY VERY spicey.  if you love HEAT or need your nasal passages cleared, this is the place for you! It wasn't greasy, but even the stuff that wasn't supposed to be hot was hot.
author: Kathryn F.

description: This is great Chinese food in a hidden alley way.  One of the only sit-down places in the area, it is always packed at lunch but I've never had a problem getting a seat.  Everything is delicious but I really liked the rock cod and potstickers.
author: Emma S.

description: Henry's Hunan is one of my favorite chinese restaurants. The food is always excellent. The dumplings are delicious. The chicken fried rice is so good and not greasy. #53. House Bean Curd Special is so yummy that people who don't normally eat tofu really like it. Diana's Meat Pie is excellent if you eat in. I'm not to thrilled when I've ordered it to go. The chicken salad is so tasty and refreshing. It comes with thinly sliced cucumbers and skinny rice noodles and lettuce. I wish I knew how to make the peanut dressing they serve with it.
author: Myra D.

description: Henry's Hunan is uber close to my office so I invariably end up going here pretty often. Normally its for someone's welcome or farewell lunch and they are very accomodating for large groups. Most dishes are on the spicy side and I love their chicken salad but we usually share multiple dishes as a group and I haven't had anything there yet that I didn't like. Try Henry's Special if its your first time. It can get crowded at lunch during the week so if you have a big group, call ahead.
author: Don O.

description: Went to lunch here for work. Lots of food, all sounded great. In the end the food was good but you better like spicy. We stuck to mild and at some point, everything started tasting the same. It kind of loses the appeal of ordering different things when all you get is spicy. I'm not huge on spicy so 3 stars but if you like spicy, it's probably a 4 star place.
author: Mike C.

description:
for being frightening looking on the outside ,it's pretty frickin good on the inside.


really sodiumy though, my feet swelled after I ate!
author: Lauren V.

description: Service has gotten better the last two times I came, but try and avoid the rush.  Try the absolutely sinful meat pie - fried goodness!  A lot of their chicken dishes are great and no matter what, there is always leftovers because they serve you so much food.  I'm starting to like this place more and more...
author: Ixchel F.

description: This is one of the places I miss most since my office moved last June. Delicious food that can occasionally be hit-or-miss, often depending on what you order. Some I went with said the food was "salty," but that made it "authentic." I'm from Fresno, so what do I know? The vegetables are always properly cooked... the asparagus dishes are a special in-season treat. Some advice: 1) Get there early. You'll get seated a lot faster, and your food will come out faster, too. 2) When they mean spicy, they mean it. Say "medium spicy" if you're used to getting "spicy" food elsewhere.
author: Aaron L.

description: went again this weekend with the family.  Excellent experience - great food and service remains excellent.
author: Greg R.

description: I adore this place.  If you like HOT food, this is THE spot.  The weekly specials are always on POINT and now they offer brown rice!  I have been here 100 times throughout my illustrious career.  This is the place to come in a big group, for a lunch date or alone.
